TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs (Mr Truss) is with us and is sitting across the chamber and this is the first opportunity I have had to actually congratulate him on his appointment as Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs. I have to say that in my time as shadow minister, which is nearly seven months now, this is my third minister. I am not sure exactly what that means, but I know that the minister still has very loyal staff behind him.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Anthony interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Spoken like the National Party. The minister has continued the very good tradition of his predecessors by making available to the opposition briefings on the issues that come before the parliament and we greatly appreciate that. The level of cooperation that has come both from the minister's own office and from the Australian Customs Service has been superb. Our questions have been answered and staff have been made available to talk to me from both your personal office and the Australian Customs Service. Where there are issues of greater significance involving other shadow ministers, that opportunity has also been taken and we certainly greatly appreciate it.

SPEECH.PARA: To make the minister's day even more, we will not be opposing the speedy passage of this legislation through the House either. This is another selection of bills dealing with issues arising out of the High Court decision that was taken some few months ago now where a challenge was launched by somebody from New South Wales about the validity of state governments to collect excise on tobacco and alcohol products and also petrol.

As a result of that, for a short period there was a mild panic in the states as to where their revenue base was going to go. I think I detected a slight smile on the face of the federal Treasurer (Mr Costello) about his increased opportunity to perhaps direct the states in certain ways. But, at the end of the day, accommodation was found and even my own state of New South Wales—although late to come to the party—certainly jumped on board and an arrangement has been put in place which will satisfy the state government and our federal government at large.

The bills collectively propose to amend the temporary Commonwealth tax safety net arrangements concerning tobacco which were implemented after the High Court invalidated the business franchise fees levied by the states and territories in relation to tobacco, alcohol and petrol. The customs and excise bills propose new arrangements for the taxation of tobacco. Prior to the High Court decision, tobacco was taxed under Commonwealth excise, which taxes on the basis of weight, and state franchise fees, which taxes on the basis of the value of the products.

The original safety net arrangement involved an increase in the Commonwealth excise of $167 per kilogram. This significantly altered the taxation of various tobacco products. This in turn would have flowed into significant alterations to retail prices and would have affected the relative profits of the manufacturers. Of course, those of the anti‐smoking lobby probably thought that was not such a bad thing.

The new proposals will replace this weight based system with a combined weight based and ad valorem system—that is a value‐based system—which equates as far as possible with the situation prior to the High Court decision. The changes under the customs and excise bills will result in a decrease of $288 million in revenue.

However, there is no financial effect on the Commonwealth as the moneys from the safety net arrangements are all on‐passed to the states and territories. Under these on‐passing arrangements, each state and territory receives a separate fixed share of the safety net revenue for tobacco, petroleum and alcohol.

As the changes have the unanimous support of the states and territories and the industry, they are, of course, non‐controversial. The bills merely attempt to replicate the situation before the High Court decision and hence minimise the commercial disruption caused. However, it is desirable to monitor the resultant position of the tobacco, petrol and alcohol industries and how they will be affected by the new system of calculating and collecting the tax payable and the resultant grants administered by the states to protect consumers.

I think one of the issues that is of great concern to us all will be that monitoring process and the effect that this will have on consumers. I think we all know that at different times, if changed taxation arrangements of some nature are put in place by governments, there is always the temptation by people who are involved in the retailing of some of those products affected by the changed taxation arrangements to perhaps tinker at the edges and go for some form of increased profit taking as a result of that.

What I am pleased by is the fact that the minister is responsible for not only Customs—and therefore this legislation—but also consumer affairs. So in that respect he has that added responsibility and capability to be able to monitor this from a consumer's perspective as well. He can just keep a tab on ensuring that there is no adverse effect on consumers by profit taking or some other means of trying to walk around this system, as we have put it in place, simply because there is a change.

We will also be monitoring the paperwork requirements for retailers and wholesalers in complying with the new regulations, because we are ever mindful of commitments given by the now Prime Minister (Mr Howard)—when he was the Leader of the Opposition and, more recently, as Prime Minister—to the small business community of this country. The commitment was that, during a very short period of time, there would be a 50 per cent reduction in the burden of paperwork on small businesses. Any changes that affect the retailing of these products brought about by changed circumstances necessitated by the passage of this legislation will, in some respects, have an impact on those compliance costs associated with the small businesses retailing these products.

We are mindful of the fact that the Prime Minister gave an ironclad guarantee to the small business community that those compliance costs and the burden of paperwork would be slashed by 50 per cent. Regrettably, what we have seen through the passage of various other pieces of legislation since this government was elected last year is that, in fact, just the opposite has occurred. Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, you know that the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1997 was debated last night in the House. In the course of those laws, there was a section relevant to the capital gains tax rollovers for small businesses. Once again, an increased compliance cost situation arose in respect of that in our view. Again, this is against the spirit of what the Prime Minister had intended.

I go also to the new requirements under superannuation. Small business proprietors now must offer their employees a choice of five superannuation funds and give explicit financial advice to those small business employees that they have as to what each of those funds are offering. So they become de facto financial advisers to their employees. I dare say that there is the potential at some stage down the track for employers to actually be sued by those employees if their advice goes awry. I would have thought that those sorts of compliance cost issues tied in, as I have suggested, with what may emerge as a result of the passage of this legislation, because it is changing the actual methodology and calculation of the way in which the excise is applied and may have a similar effect.

So we will be watching those two issues closely. Firstly, we will be watching the consumer issue which I think will be monitored by the minister because of his dual role in this area. Secondly, we will also be looking at the burden of paperwork and how it falls on those small businesses that are caught by these changes to the legislation.

At the end of the day, as I said at the outset, the opposition does not oppose this legislation. We are up to Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1997 and Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1997 arising out of the High Court decision. I know there have also been some other tariff proposals tabled in the parliament, and I dare say that they will be coming forward as legislation at some stage down the track, similarly picking up on some of the elements contained in that High Court decision.

Once again I suggest that, subject to the legislation itself, the opposition would have no objection to that. It is simply fixing up a situation that has arisen as a result of a decision taken in the High Court—one which is to the benefit of consumers, hopefully, and to the benefit of the state governments. After all we cannot see, in the absence of a broader approach to taxation reform, the states having their revenue base slashed any further by this government and still expect the states to deliver the sorts of services that people expect to have delivered to them. It is quite interesting that that sort of view is not alone here in Australia.

We seem to be on this particular path—whether it is because of changes in customs tariffs or excise tariffs amendments which we are dealing with today or whether it is because of changes to the way in which the taxation system is to be reviewed or whatever—that somehow if the Commonwealth gets out of that field, then private enterprise may pick it up or if they do not because of our system of federal government the states or local government may pick up those services. I think that is a mistaken philosophy.

I recently had the opportunity to visit New Zealand for two days and I was staggered to see that that government, in its similar quest for the bottom line, for having its budget certainly if not in balance then in surplus, was cutting back on the services that it provided from a reduced taxation background. It was cutting back on the services that it was charged with the responsibility for providing and yet asking private enterprise to pick up many of those services.

The very common criticism that I was getting—from both sides of the parliament, which is in itself interesting, and from talking to people more generally in that country—was that people felt that in social security services provision, housing, road maintenance and all of those sorts of things the government simply was not doing the right thing but was obsessed with the bottom line, obsessed with the taxation arrangements that it had put in place.

We would like to think that whatever taxation reform package this government brings forward, after the deliberations of its secret committee on this issue, it does get a very public and thorough airing. There is no doubt that we would like to participate in that process, but at this stage, like most others in the Australian community, we have been frozen out. Any of those broader views of taxation reform particularly where it involves changes to state and territory based sources of revenue—because, at the end of day, that is a major contentious point of argument still—needs to take into consideration things like the legislative base for what is being dealt with here today.

I see my good friend the member for the Northern Territory (Mr Dondas) is here and he, from his Legislative Assembly background in the Northern Territory, knows full well that when changes occur, as a result of changes at the federal level, to the way in which revenues are distributed to the states and territories that places an onerous burden on the states and territories. They are expected to pick revenue up from other sources of revenue raising, from additional taxes or whatever it might be.

I hope that the taxation reform proposal that might emerge out of the deliberations of that committee—closeted away down in Treasury, PM&C or wherever they might be—will take into consideration, as part of that broader reform process, the sorts of issues we are dealing with here and the reasons we are having to deal with this legislation today. I conclude by reaffirming that the opposition does not oppose the passage of this legislation. We wish it speedy passage through this chamber and also through the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the remarks made by my colleague the shadow minister for small business and customs, the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Martin). The legislation before us in this debate is the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1997 [No. 2] and the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1997 . What these bills collectively propose to do is to amend the temporary Commonwealth tax safety net arrangements concerning tobacco which were implemented after the High Court invalidated the business franchise fees levied by the states in relation to tobacco, alcohol and petrol.

SPEECH.PARA: The customs and excise bills propose new arrangements for the taxation of tobacco. As members will be aware, prior to the High Court decision, tobacco and tobacco products were taxed under Commonwealth excise, which taxes on the basis of weight, and the state franchise fees, which tax on the basis of the value of the products. The total taxation regime on tobacco was an amalgam of both a weight based tax and a value based tax.

Leaving aside arguments about whether the taxation situation which existed prior to the High Court's ruling was the optimal situation or not, the fact remains that the industry was operating on that basis. Given the high rate of tax payable on tobacco products, any substantial alteration to the taxation regime can be expected to have potentially significant commercial effects. The changes flow into the wholesale and retail prices of various products, and the relative profits of the industry participants therefore vary considerably.

Estimates put to the opposition by some members of the industry were that the annual effects of a change to only weight based taxation would be of the order of around $30 million per annum. A change of this magnitude would obviously have potentially significant employment impacts, especially in some regional areas.

The government knew about this problem when it enacted the original safety net arrangements. However, as further evidence of the government's poor planning prior to the High Court decision, no arrangements had been agreed with the states to overcome the problem and so allow a smooth transition to the new Commonwealth only tax regime. Instead, what we got was an increase in the Commonwealth excise of $167 per kilogram. This level of increase in excise was too high to merely replace the revenue lost from the state tobacco taxes which were invalidated.

In addition, the use of the excise base introduced these commercial distortions relative to the prior situation. The new proposals are going to replace the weight based system with a combined weight based and ad valorem or value based system which equates as far as possible with the situation prior to the High Court's decision.

The changes in these bills are complex and involve the replacement of the $167 increase with the options of, firstly, a hybrid rate based on a combination of a weight based rate per kilogram of 50.32 per cent of the gazetted wholesale list price for a particular product or, secondly, a solely weight based duty rate only where no wholesale list price has been gazetted.

Under the particular arrangements applying under customs and excise legislation, changes which are properly gazetted come into effect before the relevant legislation is passed by the parliament. The changes in these two bills were gazetted on 16 September and have operated since 17 September. Those bills merely formalise the decisions which have been operating for the previous six weeks.

The changes under the customs and excise bill will result in a decrease of $288 million in revenue. There is, however, no actual net financial effect on the Commonwealth because all of the moneys which are collected under the safety net arrangements of the collection and other administrative costs incurred by the Commonwealth are then passed on to the states and territories. A decrease in the gross level of collections does not affect the financial position of the Commonwealth as the decrease is completely offset by a similar reduction in the grants passed on to the states.
In keeping with Labor's cooperation on the issues arising from the High Court's decision on the states' business franchise fees, the opposition is supporting these bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss, Warren, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr TRUSS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) and the member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) for their contribution to the debate and, in particular, also acknowledge the appreciation of the government to the opposition for granting a speedy passage of the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1997 [No. 2] and the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 5) . In supporting the bills, they are endorsing the unanimous wish of the states that this change be made to the way in which the excise duty is collected on certain tobacco products following the High Court decision.

SPEECH.PARA: I also thank the member for Cunningham for his kind comments on my appointment to the ministry. I assure him, in his absence, that as minister I certainly will continue the practice of predecessors to ensure that the opposition is well briefed on matters that come before the parliament. I think it is a very important aspect of the parliamentary process that all members of parliament, including opposition members, are well informed about the issues.

BREAK.PARA: Hopefully, by adopting an open house and an attitude that will result in the opposition being aware of what the issues are, we may win their support on other occasions in the future. I acknowledge, however, that from time to time there will be reasons for them to oppose legislation. Of course, we respect their right and their obligation in some circumstances to do that. I am certainly anxious to work with the honourable member for Cunningham or any successors as shadow minister for customs to ensure that legislation has a smooth passage through the House wherever possible.

The member for Cunningham raised a couple of issues which I would like to comment on. One was not of great substance. He mentioned that this was the fifth piece of legislation arising out of the High Court decision and I suspect he gained that impression because this was Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1997 , but in fact some of the earlier bills were not related to High Court matters. I think this is actually the third piece of legislation arising out of the High Court decision. But, certainly, that decision has required a response from the government and we have always indicated a willingness to work with the states to achieve a satisfactory outcome following that decision.

The member for Cunningham also made some observations in relation to the importance of reducing paperwork for small business and he referred to the commitment by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) for the government to do what it can to reduce the paper burden on small business. There have been a number of very significant initiatives by the government to reduce paperwork. Of course, everyone in small business would acknowledge that it is perhaps state and local governments that are responsible for the majority of the paperwork imposed on their operations. But the Commonwealth has been prepared to act and has demonstrated its willingness to act wherever it can. There have already been a number of initiatives which will reduce paperwork for small business.

Ironically, one of the effects of this particular piece of legislation, although not the prime purpose, is that it will have a major impact on reducing small business paperwork. For those who had been associated with the old franchise fees, they will no longer have to fill out any of the paperwork associated with those taxes which the High Court has ruled to be unconstitutional. Retailers will have no paperwork associated with this new measure and I think they will welcome the simplicity, from their point of view, of this new measure. So from the point of view of paperwork, there will actually be advances as part of this legislation.

The member for Cunningham also referred to the importance of dealing with the questions of state revenue as part of the tax reform process that the federal government is currently undertaking. Obviously, vertical fiscal imbalance will be on the agenda. It must be on the agenda in dealing with the future taxation regime that our nation wants to put in place for the next century. Those are the sorts of issues which will be under consideration by the government in that process.

I notice that he felt that he was being excluded. I can assure him that the government would welcome contributions by the opposition to tax debate. It is probably time we heard some of their ideas about how the tax system should be reformed, other than their only contribution to date which I understand has been on death duties, which is one that is not attractive to the government side, I can tell you. But if you have worthwhile ideas and would like to contribute to the debate, we are looking forward to hearing them.

To summarise, this legislation is supported by both sides of the House and by all of the states, and I welcome its speedy passage. The bill will change the way in which excise duties and customs duties in relation to bill No. 5 are levied on certain tobacco products, and will lead to a system which, as the honourable member for Wills says, is a little more complicated but more closely replicates the arrangements that existed previously. The arrangements will shift from a solely weight based surcharge to one based on both weight and value. There will be some revenue loss to the states associated with this measure, but the fact that they have unanimously supported these new arrangements demonstrates that they are prepared to accept those changes. So I commend the bill to the Main Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —If no member wishes to consider the bill in detail, I will put the report question forthwith. The question is that this bill be reported to the House without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 22 October, on motion by Mr Truss:
That the bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.
Debate resumed from 23 October, on motion by Mr Miles:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 proposes to give effect to a request by the states and territories to alter their shares of revenue replacement payments for tobacco under the safety net arrangements. These altered relativities arise from the change in the method of imposing tax. This bill is directly related to the previous two revenue bills which we were just discussing, but it was not possible to cognately debate them, hence this brief separate debate. I therefore will not canvass again the changes to the customs and excise regime that have caused this bill to come forward.

SPEECH.PARA: Under these on‐passing arrangements relating to the safety net package, each state and territory receives a separate fixed share of the safety net revenue for tobacco, petroleum and alcohol, arising from the new government impost on each of these products. The bill proposes to alter the shares of the individual states and territories for the tobacco payments only. The changes have been agreed to by all the states and territories and hence are not opposed by Labor. For the record, the beneficiaries of these new arrangements will be Western Australia, South Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory.

The bill is also seeking authority to set any future changes to the distribution of alcohol, tobacco and petrol revenues by regulation to avoid the need for additional legislation. While oppositions are always a little suspicious of the motives of governments who propose to replace a legislative outcome with one which is covered and can be altered by a regulation, we do not oppose the proposition in this legislation.

In the case where a future alteration of the relativities has been agreed to by all the states and territories, that is a proper situation in which a regulation could be appropriate to set the agreed relativities. Where there is not agreement—for example, where a change would be manifestly unfair to one or other of the states—the regulation would, of course, be disallowable in either the House or the Senate. Decisions relating to disallowance would have to be made, depending on the particular circumstances obtaining at the time. It is not possible to set down now the opposition's future position on particular questions that may arise. I merely make the point that there is an option for disallowance if necessary by the parliament.

This bill is simply attempting, along with those in the prior debate, to replicate the situation before the High Court decision and, hence, to minimise the commercial disruption caused. The opposition supports this objective and we will be facilitating this by supporting this bill.

The Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs (Mr Truss) mentioned in the previous debate the issue of paperwork, and he suggested that this might be an advance on the paperwork front. The opposition queries this, and it occurs to us that one downside of the new regime is that the paperwork of small businesses may be increased due to the system of rebates paid by the state and territory governments to offset the new uniform Commonwealth taxes. The opposition will be closely monitoring these systems to ensure to the best of our ability that the burden of paperwork does not become unreasonable. We are mindful of the government's promise to halve the paperwork burden for small business—a promise which has been spectacularly broken by the government. I note that the minister for customs was starting to talk about the states and local governments having responsibility for the red tape burden on small business.

The changes which are being proposed in this bill have the support of the opposition and we hope that with these changes, which are certainly the fourth bill to come before the House, we have finally dealt with the result of the High Court decision and restored the situation obtaining before the High Court's judgment, as far as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dondas, Nick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 . The measures contained in this bill are to counter the result of the High Court ruling on 5 August this year, which found that the New South Wales franchise fee on tobacco was constitutionally invalid. The Northern Territory government requested legal advice on their own position, advice which confirmed that the Territory's business franchise fees on tobacco were also invalid. Similar fees on alcohol and petroleum were also deemed to be constitutionally questionable and, in light of the tobacco ruling, probably invalid. This caused enormous fiscal uncertainty for the states and territories. They relied on these fees to the tune of some $5 billion per year, which constituted between 15 and 17 per cent of their total taxation revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer of the Northern Territory, the Hon. Mike Reed MLA, wrote to the federal Treasurer, along with the other state treasurers, to request the urgent assistance of the Commonwealth in order to resolve these problems. To its credit, the Commonwealth acted quickly to put in place a safety net arrangement to ensure that the states and territories could avoid the serious budgetary implications posed by the decision. I know the Northern Territory government appreciated the speed with which the Commonwealth implemented the alternative collection strategy.

The provisions of the safety net allow for the Commonwealth to use its taxation powers to collect, on behalf of the states, the revenue the states used to collect on petroleum products, tobacco and alcohol. The safety net arrangements had two parts. The first aspect was that the Commonwealth levies were increased on products formerly covered by business franchise fees. As the constitution requires, the Commonwealth has to apply taxes uniformly across the country. Therefore, the differing tax rates that the states and the territories had in place could not be taken as a guide for each jurisdiction.

As a consequence, the safety net rates were higher in some states than previously collected under the business franchise fees. Where the Commonwealth surcharge was greater than the Territory business franchise fees, the Territory government offered subsidies to wholesalers who did not increase their prices in line with the Commonwealth levy. The Territory government also gave priority to ensuring that motorists, including off‐road users, were not disadvantaged and that the prices of petroleum products and tobacco products would not increase. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission was called in to monitor the movement of prices of these products to ensure that they did not increase needlessly.

The second aspect of the safety net arrangements was the introduction of a windfall gains tax to protect state and territory budgets from refund claims in respect of past business franchise fee payments. The windfall gains tax will apply at a rate of 100 per cent and has been imposed by the Commonwealth at the request of the states and territories. Any revenue gained by the Commonwealth through windfall gains tax will be reimbursed to the states and the territories.

The windfall tax applies to refunds sought by taxpayers for payments made before 5 August 1997. The government will ensure that the introduction of the windfall gains tax does not result in double taxation effect. The revenues collected from the Commonwealth's replacement of business franchise fees are reimbursed back to the states and territories, less Commonwealth administrative costs, as revenue replacement payments under the States Grants (General Purposes) Act 1994. The method and distribution of the revenue is as formulated and agreed by the states and territories and set out in a schedule to the act. These shares are based on the Commonwealth Grants Commission estimates of 1996‐1997 business franchise fee revenue bases. These arrangements will be reviewed by the states and territories in six months.

The States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill 1997 has two main purposes. Firstly, the bill will introduce a request by the states and territories to adjust their share of revenue replacement payments for tobacco as established under the current safety net arrangements. Secondly, it will allow future changes in state and territory revenue replacement shares to be made by regulation rather than by legislative amendment. The states have requested that the Commonwealth alter the shares for tobacco related payments as a part of the new arrangements for the taxation of tobacco under the provisions of the safety net.

Due to the difficulties of administering a rebate for tobacco, the states and territories have negotiated their own package with the tobacco industry. This new arrangement would see a lower revenue target and a shift from a weight based surcharge to one based on both weight and value.

The federal government will be introducing a separate bill in order to deal with the revenue side of these new arrangements, although a surcharge rate is expected to reduce by $290 million the surcharge on tobacco resulting in a revenue of around $3 billion in a full year. The lower rate of revenue collected on tobacco could have resulted in some states being worse off financially because of the High Court decision. The states have therefore requested the Commonwealth to adjust the distribution of the revenue to ensure that no state is worse off financially than it was before 5 August.

As stated earlier, these arrangements are up for review in six months. By allowing for future changes to be made by regulation rather than legislation it will provide the flexibility which is essential should the states and territories need to alter their existing shares when they review the safety net arrangements after six months. Any change in the share allocation would only happen at the request and unanimous agreement of the states and territories. Consistent with the government's aim to avoid price increases in alcohol and petroleum, this legislation when passed will return tobacco revenue to the states and territories with a minimum of delay.

One of the most important issues confronting our federation today is the vertical fiscal imbalance that leaves our states and territories in a weaker financial position than the constitution intended. It is crucial when we talk of tax reform that we consider the position of the states and territories and work to strengthen their financial position. I understand this policy of a higher level of fiscal independence for the states has strong support. I hope that this issue will be examined in some detail by the government's tax consultative task force, and I expect it might also get some exposure at next year's constitutional convention here in Canberra.

The decision handed down by the High Court this year shows the extent of the difficulties faced by the states and territories when budgeting for the provision of essential services. Overnight they had about $5 billion disappear from their revenue base.

I commend the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Treasurer (Mr Costello) for the speed with which they stepped in to arrange alternative collection payments on behalf of the states. It showed a commitment to our federal system and I am sure it eased the minds of our state and territory governments. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hardgrave, Gary, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 . It is a decisive, straightforward and sensible measure which picks up the difficulties that were created by the High Court decision on 5 August which affected state business franchise fees, essentially the collection of fees on petroleum products, tobacco and alcoholic beverages. They were matters which went to the heart of states' revenue and, in turn, to the expenditure on so many important and essential services in my electorate by the state government of Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill gives effect to a straightforward request from the states to alter their share of revenue replacement payments for tobacco under safety net arrangements. It is important to note that there was so much at stake. As the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Dondas) and others in this debate have suggested, the vertical fiscal imbalance where essentially the states rely on the Commonwealth for so much of their revenue is something which can be addressed through the course of taxation reform, a debate which is ongoing in this country at the moment. That imbalance has certainly been a fact of life since the state governments lost their capacity to levy income tax back in 1942, a wartime measure that has continued to be a way of life in Australia ever since the Second World War.

The total of general purpose grants to the states in the budget this year totalled $16.83 billion, mainly in the form of financial assistance grants. Obviously, that is a lot of money and it is very important to the various states. As a result of the High Court decision in August there was going to be quite a large hole in the budgets of the various states unless the Commonwealth acted as it is doing in this bill.

For that reason this bill will pass in this place without any dissension from the opposition, and I welcome their support. Of course, part of the overall planning as far as financial arrangements between the states and the Commonwealth are concerned this year have included the second repayment of some money back to the Commonwealth in the form of fiscal assistance which is a payment, a fiscal contribution, from the states back to the Commonwealth to help mend the $10 billion black hole left by the previous government. The states and the Commonwealth are obviously working very closely, as is evidenced in this bill, on matters relating to financial arrangements.

I thought it was important to recount to this place just how the Queensland state government has been expending moneys given by the Commonwealth under this legislation, and doing a very good job in the last 18 months. In fact, the Queensland state Treasurer, the Hon. Joan Sheldon, and the Premier, the Hon. Rob Borbidge, said that, despite the High Court ruling in August, Queensland was committed to remaining a low tax state—in fact, the lowest taxing state government in the Commonwealth. There will be no changes to this government policy, and no increases to taxes and charges above the CPI.

Despite the fiscal contribution demands of the Commonwealth, and despite the actions and decisions of the High Court, these challenges are still being very effectively met by the Queensland government. They have been met with a point of greater efficiency in the delivery of services—in fact, the delivery of more services than had been the case under the previous Labor government led by Wayne Goss. There are tax cuts taking place in Queensland: tax cuts for individuals, for land-holders and for small business. There seems to be an ongoing program of announcements, including the largest capital works program ever delivered by a Queensland government.

In fact, the most recent budget by the state government in Queensland has provided record spending with the emphasis on tax cuts, delivery of services, capital works and jobs. It is all about helping business do better, create jobs and reduce the current level of unemployment, particularly among the young. In this regard, I think the Queensland state government should be congratulated for the way it is working with the Commonwealth to ensure the delivery of these very important and straightforward demands of our constituents.

The Queensland government's recent budget also focused on giving some hope, help and incentive to rural areas devastated by drought and commodity downturns. For those members who are not from the state of Queensland, particularly the south‐east corner, the impact of the drought and the commodity downturn on various aspects of life, including business life, is noticeable in the state.

In addition to the demands of the Commonwealth, the Queensland state government has made savings of about half a billion dollars against forward estimates of the previous government for 1996‐97 and, quite sensibly, it has put those savings back into core services. The budget has delivered 1,000 new teachers, 252 more police, 500 extra doctors, nurses and health workers, but, more importantly, 50,000 jobs for Queenslanders. As far as police numbers go, the government is well ahead of its target. There were 6,566 officers in the force at the end of June 1997, up 160 on the previous year and 21 more than the government had targeted. The commitment to provide the extra 252 police officers this year is certainly going to be met. A further 200 officers are being freed from desk duties.

On that law and order front, the government has also provided some practical and strong support in the way of legislation to deal with crime. Queensland now has some of the nation's toughest laws with violent criminals to serve at least 80 per cent of their sentence. With respect to juvenile crime, 50 per cent of all motor vehicle thefts were committed by males aged 15 to 19, with 584 offenders aged 14 years or younger. There were 111 sex offenders in the 10 to 14 age group and 189 in the 15 to 19 age group. Despite accounting for only 23 per cent of the total population, offenders in the 10 to 24 age bracket were responsible for 83 per cent of all break and enter crimes. These matters will be dealt with very strongly as a result of the new Juvenile Justice Act, brought in by the Attorney‐General in Queensland, the Hon. Denver Beanland, MLA.

As I said, I think the Queensland government, despite the challenges of the High Court, and despite the need to make fiscal contributions back to the Commonwealth to fill in the Beazley black hole, is doing incredibly well. In my own electorate, I am very pleased to see that the Hon. Mike Horan, the health minister, has effected a rebirth of the QEII hospital, which is near the centre of my electorate and is vital to the electorate. To the absolute disgrace of the previous government—which was not facing the sorts of pressures that the current Queensland government is facing in demands from the Commonwealth, in demands from the High Court and, for that matter, the tightness of the numbers in Queensland where the government needs the support of the independent, Mrs Cunningham—it allowed the QEII hospital to run down to the point where it was to be mothballed and closed up.

In fact, the absolute disgrace of this was that the charge was led by the Premier of the state, Wayne Goss, in his efforts to enhance a hospital in his own electorate against a hospital that had been in his electorate when he was first elected. Some of the people in my area will be in the electorate of Rankin. If Mr Goss is to run there, he will find that that will haunt him. If Mr Goss is to run in the electorate of Oxley, he will find that a lot of people in that electorate will also remember his role in destroying the QEII hospital.

Mike Horan has rejuvenated QEII. In fact, $2.4 billion is being spent over 10 years on a hospital rebuilding program—a $733 million increase in capital works. The previous health minister before the honourable Mike Horan is now the opposition leader in Queensland, Mr Beattie.

TALK.START.PARA: —A disaster.

—He was an absolute disaster. The member for Dickson is quite correct. When the next state election comes around, Mr Beattie too will be reminded by the people in my electorate how poor a health minister he really was.

SPEECH.PARA: This year's Queensland budget provided $42.9 million exclusively to reduce category 2 elective surgery waiting lists as part of the coalition government's successful surgery on time program. It also maintained the current category 1 elective surgery long wait target at less than five per cent of the patients waiting longer than the recommended maximum 30 days.

In fact, Queensland now has the best category 1 elective surgery waiting list figures in Australia, after having the very worst under the previous Labor government led by the now opposition leader Peter Beattie. New public hospital projects in Queensland pushed building approvals to a record $535 million, according to the Queensland Master Builders Association, in July of this year.

In a general sense, Queensland fares much better than Victoria in any comparison of economic growth—27 per cent growth in trend terms since 1992 compared with Victoria's 21 per cent. I am sure the Victorian members here today would be very envious of a 27 per cent growth. Queensland also leads all other states in development of retail building and educational, health and community facilities. Brisbane has also superseded Melbourne as Australia's second largest international gateway to Australia and is the fastest growing international and domestic airport.

All of this means that the funds provided by the Commonwealth to the Queensland state government are being very well spent. They are being very well targeted on the real issues by Treasurer Sheldon. As far as jobs are concerned, Queensland has generated 63 per cent of all new jobs created in Australia over the last year or so, and 48,500 jobs have been created, which is an amazing result. Queensland's annual employment growth of two per cent is five times the national annual growth of 0.4 per cent.

The state government is also committed to better social infrastructure for Queensland, such as schools and hospitals. Around Queensland, 1,300 state schools are being upgraded with capital works allocations of $273 million, and $300 million is to be spent in 1997‐98 on rail projects serving Queensland's coal and mining industry. All in all, we are seeing tremendous activity and great achievements by the Queensland state government, and very effective expenditure of the money which is generated by the Commonwealth and granted to them.

There are a lot of reasons why it is important to state these facts on the record here in Canberra. I think it is important for all honourable members to realise that, as the states grants matters are discussed each year and the crises come and go and vertical fiscal imbalance discussions occur on an annual basis, in the case of Queensland, its annual growth rate of population is 2.5 per cent compared to one per cent for New South Wales, and 0.6 per cent for Victoria. The national rate is 1.2 per cent, so Queensland is having an ever increasing demand on Commonwealth revenue to ensure that facilities can not only be delivered for the current needs, but also be planned for the future. In the past five years, the population of Queensland grew by 12.7 per cent—more than double the national growth of six per cent.

It is folklore in the southern states that a lot of this comes about because retirees are moving to Queensland. Rather, the official figures show that younger people are moving their homes and families to Queensland to benefit from the better economic conditions, lower taxes, higher quality of life and robust and secure economic future. Queensland migration survey figures indicate that interstate migrants coming to Queensland are more likely than not to be in the 25 to 45 age group. All the challenges to provide schools, to provide law and order through more police and to provide improved hospital facilities are being met by the Queensland state government.

It is very important to know that a lot of big companies, as well, are voting with their feet for the performance of the Queensland state government. In fact, the Boeing company is going to shift its Australian corporate headquarters from Sydney to Brisbane to become the hub of the $US48 billion a year corporation's Australian defence and aerospace operations. Three hundred jobs are expected to be created in Queensland by the end of next year, adding to the jobs of relocated headquarters staff. Nearly 20 major national and international companies have relocated their head offices or key divisions to Queensland in the past 12 months, in the life of the Borbidge‐Sheldon government.

Essentially, since the Queensland's government's policy agenda commenced to flow through the community and economy, billions of dollars worth of major development projects have been earmarked for the state. The full investment involved is $7.5 billion, with possible job generation of 11,600 people.

This is a great achievement, and it is worth noting and recounting to the parliament just how well the Queensland state government is performing. In fact, it has implemented 90 per cent of the policies it took to the people of Queensland at the July 1995 election. All of this has been done despite not having an absolute majority in the legislative assembly in Queensland.

It is worth noting that in 1995 the Goss Labor government had a substantial majority but sat on its hands and failed to do so many things. One of the things that governments of all persuasions, though, have failed to do in my electorate is a matter about which I have spoken to the new Minister for Transport and Regional Development, the Hon. Mark Vaile. It is a matter about which I have spoken also to the state transport minister in Queensland, the Hon. Vaughan Johnson, and I have raised it with council officers as well. I refer to the Coopers Plains level crossing over Boundary Road. For the last 25 or 30 years there has been a crying need for this.

The people of Coopers Plains supported the Goss government very strongly in 1989 and in 1992. They did not in 1995 because they basically thought that after six years of Labor they would have seen results of something that the previous coalition government never quite got around to doing.

This level crossing has heavy trucks travelling across the main arterial railway line between Brisbane and the Gold Coast. Increased railway passenger usage means that there are many more trains travelling across it now than five years ago. Yet nothing has been done to address the need for a proper, reliable crossing there. People have been killed at this crossing; people have been injured in car and truck accidents. There has been some alleviation and some improvement to the site by changes in signalling made by the city council, but there is still a crying need for major capital works.

I know that financial assistance grants under the state grants act do go now to assisting with road and infrastructure in the various states, and I certainly look forward to continuing my role in advocating that something be done about the need for this crossing and in ensuring that the federal government plays its role. But there really is a challenge for the state government to plan, in concert with the Brisbane City Council, what it would like to have there. I think that is a challenge that transport minister Vaughan Johnson can take up.

I am sure that, with the range of quality people endorsed by the Liberal Party in the general area—the first Taiwanese born Australian state candidate, Steven Huang in Sunnybank; Fazal Deen, in Archerfield; John Webster, in Yeronga; and councillor Graham Quirk, in Mount Gravatt—we are going to see some very strong advocates for the cause of the Coopers Plains level crossing between now and the next state election. If each of those four good local people—with strong local connections, having been educated and lived for many years in the areas that they would like to represent—is actually elected to the state parliament in Queensland, I know I will have working with me some very strong advocates for those sorts of basic needs.

BREAK.PARA: In closing, it is important that the Queensland government keep up the good work. Despite the challenges that have been placed on them because of the $10 billion Beazley black hole to make a contribution in a fiscal sense back to the Commonwealth to play its part in paying back this huge budget deficit the Howard government was left with, and despite the fact that the High Court has added to the challenge by saying that they cannot collect what were traditional fees on tobacco, alcohol and petroleum products, I think the Queensland government continues to rise to the challenge and must continue to do so for the benefit of people in my electorate of Moreton.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the comments of the member for Moreton (Mr Hardgrave). Not only is the Queensland state government a minority government in terms of its need to depend on an independent to get legislation through; it also has a very hostile daily press—in particular, the daily newspaper the Courier‐Mail , which is constantly running anti‐government lines and repeatedly misrepresenting the situation as far as that government is concerned, wherever possible, and also an at times hostile local suburban press—all owned by the one newspaper proprietor, all part of the Murdoch empire.

SPEECH.PARA: It really goes to show yet again those wise words of the former Prime Minister Mr Fraser, when he said that it was very dangerous to have a media system where one or two proprietors could run the agenda in the country. It is something that we should take heed of. In particular, as Queenslanders, certainly we see it daily. I get more complaints about the Courier‐Mail newspaper and its line and its bias than almost any other issue when I travel around the electorate. What we do need is a competitive alternative, but it is very difficult and very costly to start that up.

But turning to the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill (No. 2) before the House, I am pleased to support this legislation, which came about as a result of the recent High Court decision on franchise fees. I have spoken before about the need for tax reform. I think there are many members on this side of the House that have. Indeed, the government has appointed a committee to look into that—a very strong and very sensible committee. It is opportune to congratulate one person, in particular. Although I do not want to necessarily single anyone out, the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) has been at the forefront of the need for tax reform. I just want to say that a lot of the agenda on tax reform has been very much pushed by the honourable member for O'Connor. I think that he deserves great credit and I am very pleased to see that he is on this committee.

The High Court decision highlights yet again the incredibly difficult milieu surrounding Commonwealth‐state relations, in particular on the core issue of tax—the very clumsy system that we seem to have where the Commonwealth collects most of the tax but the states provide most of the services. The particular imbalance that arises by a history of, particularly, legislative measures in the last 50 or so years, the passage of time, the change in orientation generally and a centralist orientated—at times—High Court really has left a noose that was maybe once, a few years ago, maybe 20 or 30 years ago, dangling around the states' necks and has now been tightened more and more. I do not think it bodes well for our future of federation unless we come to terms with the need for tax reform.

Recently I had a lengthy discussion with a man called Vince Cini, who is the proprietor of a business in Lawnton in my electorate called Pressed Plywood Products. Mr Cini runs a very good business, but over a period of time he explained to me that he does not believe that, the way the system is going, his business can survive much longer.

BREAK.PARA: Only a couple of years ago Vince Cini had 30 staff. He is now down to 11. He pointed out to me during the course of our discussions that a number of other manufacturers that he is aware of in the same business have been experiencing a similar problem, one particular manufacturer in recent times having cut its work force down from 85 to 25.

He told me about his business. Basically, what he does is make moulds. He illustrated this by referring to an example. Right in this room there are numerous chairs and in those chairs are ply mouldings. His company makes those ply mouldings. He does a very good job of it. He showed me an example of his work and then he showed me an example of some imports. The imports are only marginally cheaper, although obviously the price of the product in bulk is a lot less. But there is no doubt in my mind that the imported product is grossly inferior in every way to the Australian product, and in particular to his product.

I said to him, `We need to change the tax system, don't we?' He said something to me which I think has been forgotten in this debate. He said, `You've got to have wealth first. You cannot tax something that is not there. You've got to actually be making money for tax to be drawn on that profit.' I thought that was a very good, simple point, because you cannot talk about tax in a vacuum. He said, `You start with a business making money.' The thing that you have to look at in all of that is the question of business inputs.

When he started discussing this, I then reflected on the Commonwealth, state and local government interaction in respect of the cost of business inputs and the effect that all of this has on people who are in a very small operation, but nonetheless a large one in terms of what this man is producing. He spoke of various things. One particular matter he mentioned was the environmental levy. He uses very user‐friendly environmental materials. He uses plantation forest timber and a water‐based glue for gluing the ply and he has the machinery to effect the gluing of the ply.

I inspected the factory last week and I could not detect anything in the nature of an offensive smell. It was a very pleasant and clean environment and yet he has been charged $700 per annum environmental levy, when the gluing product he is using—which is the major product concerned said to be sufficient to attract that levy—is a 99 per cent organic product. Seven hundred dollars may not sound much, but you have to add it to the myriad of other business inputs and then reflect on why this is happening. Why is a levy like that put on such a business? It is dragging down his competitiveness and making him less competitive with that inferior product.

The reason has to be that there is this problem with our tax system which is causing more and more little levies and additions to spring up. I need not go into payroll tax. That is yet another one which certainly has to be redressed, because that is a tax on employment. Again, that is another one of those things which forces his input cost up and makes him less competitive. Indeed, he has got to a stage where he has been made offers by overseas interests to move his factory lock, stock and barrel overseas and been offered very attractive terms for doing so. It is a real worry. There were 30 people working there a couple of years ago; there are 11 now. There may not be any more soon. It is important that we address these inputs. The cost of workers compensation is an extraordinary impost. He told me about the cost of that.

I am the first to say that workers have to be protected. I do believe in common law rights; I do not believe in the system of workers compensation at fixed rates and no common law action. However, having said that, my experience of doing workers compensation cases over the years was that the workers compensation board was the most inefficient organisation that you could possibly imagine. Cases where liability screamed out at you would not be settled until you were at the door of the court. All of the costs involved in that procedure were incurred along the way. The $30,000 or $40,000 in legal costs could have been avoided if the board had taken a more realistic approach.

The government that was elected in Queensland in 1996 has certainly redressed a lot of that and has streamlined the board. Nonetheless, that has a very marked effect on Mr Cini's business, along with those matters that I have referred to. There are a number of other things too, but all of these things make his business less competitive and less able to deal with the imports.

Then Mr Cini told me this story, which was extraordinary. He became aware of a particular company that was buying these mouldings, and the company buying the mouldings had bought them from England. The product was inferior and it was marginally more expensive than what he was making them for. Eventually the English company got very interested and said, `Look, you can make them cheaper. Why don't you do it?' So he said, `Yes, I will. I can supply you.' So some negotiations took place. Then the UK government put a 45 per cent tariff on his item.

So it really is quite extraordinary. I could go on for a long time about this particular issue, but I guess it is all bound up with the fact that we do need reform of our tax system to help those small businesses. The question has been asked before whether, if this tax system is fixed up—we need to do it, and do it quickly and do it in a bipartisan way—we would have a problem with tariffs. I think there are a lot of people who take the view that, if our system were fixed up, we would be producing things at a better rate and be much more competitive because of the lower cost of inputs. So I support the measures but, yet again, ring the bell on tax reform for this country. I hope that the bell is heard by those on the other side who, to date, have used it often for political purposes.

TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—First, I will thank the member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson), the member for the Northern Territory (Mr Dondas), the member for Moreton (Mr Hardgrave) and the member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) for their contributions to this debate. Both sides of the House recognise the importance of doing something in respect of the High Court ruling on 5 August 1997, when challenges were launched in the cases of Ha and Walter Hammond and Associates against the New South Wales franchise fees on tobacco. It involved around $5.2 billion of tax revenue to the states. Clearly, there had to be an arrangement made.

SPEECH.PARA: Following the High Court ruling in that decision, the states and territories unanimously approached the Commonwealth—I just want to emphasise the fact that it was a unanimous approach by the states and territories to the Commonwealth—with a request for a safety net. The Commonwealth agreed to that request. I guess we could have said no, but commonsense in these matters means that there should be an arrangement worked out. I want to emphasise a few matters that relate to the safety net requested by the states and territories involved, because I know that the debate has been reasonably wide ranging and not directly on this particular matter, and that is fair enough in the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 debate. In encapsulating the ideas in regard to this bill specifically, I would like to go through some details.

The safety net which was requested by the states and territories involved four things: firstly, a surcharge being placed on Commonwealth taxes on alcohol, tobacco and petroleum; secondly, surcharge revenues being forwarded to the states and territories less an amount to cover the Commonwealth for admin costs; thirdly, the surcharge revenue being distributed to the states and territories on the basis of distribution shares requested by them and set out in a schedule to the States Grants (General Purposes) Act 1994; and, fourthly, a windfall gains tax at the rate of 100 per cent so as to protect the states and territories from refund claims.

The safety net arrangements are intended to be temporary and will be reviewed within six months. With regard to tobacco, there were a lot of complexities in this particular issue, and the safety net arrangements involved an increase of $167 per kilogram in the customs and excise duty on tobacco products. This weight based tax surcharge differed from the state and territory systems which were based on value. So there were complexities which came out of that.

The Commonwealth, states and territories have separately held extensive discussions with the tobacco industry and agreement was reached between the states and territories and the industry and most of the details were announced by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) on 11 September.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was making some comments about tobacco and the difference between the way in which the states and the Commonwealth were levying the charges, excise and so forth. The Commonwealth and states and territories have separately held very extensive discussions with the tobacco industry, and an agreement was reached between the states and territories and the industry. Most of the details were announced by the Treasurer on 11 September.

SPEECH.PARA: That agreement included three key points. Firstly, the tax take from tobacco products on behalf of states and territories would be cut from a full year amount of $3.261 billion to $2.973 billion. Secondly, the states and territories would not pay rebates to consumers to compensate for the increase in the outgoing amount of revenue being collected from the tobacco. Thirdly, a hybrid weight based ad valorem surcharge would be introduced so as to make for a taxation system which more closely modelled state and territory franchise fees. Following the Commonwealth government's acceptance of a request by the states and territories to implement these arrangements, they were put into place by the Australian Customs Service.

Another aspect to the legislation is the regulation making power. The bill also seeks to allow future changes in tobacco, petroleum or alcohol revenues to be prescribed by regulation. This will provide flexibility, should the review of the safety net arrangements to be conducted within six months give rise to further requests by the states to alter the existing shares. In practice, any change to the distribution of tobacco, petroleum or alcohol revenues, would be unanimously requested by the states.

In regard to price rises, there has been some comment about price rises and I will make a few brief background comments. There was some criticism of recent arrangements reached between the states and territories and the tobacco industry and announced on 11 September. This was because it was accompanied by predictions of a 2 per cent to 2.5 per cent increase in tobacco prices, reflecting the fact that no rebates would be paid while the gross state and territory take from tobacco would increase from $2.885 billion to $2.973 billion in a full year. However, the initial safety net arrangements—involving a revenue target of $3.261 billion, some states refusing to pay rebates and the others having no suitable rebate arrangement in place—could have seen even higher increases in tobacco prices.

BREAK.PARA: There is little the Commonwealth can do to force prices down. All of the money raised on behalf of the states and territories is being returned to them except for a small amount for administrative costs. The responsibility for addressing price rises therefore rests with the state governments. I want to underline that fact, that any price increases rest with the state governments, not with the Commonwealth government. The Commonwealth is constitutionally prohibited from requiring that the states pay a rebate as this would run the risk of being seen by the High Court as discriminatory taxation.

Concerning the new taxation arrangement, the initial safety net arrangements involved a customs and excise duty surcharge on tobacco and tobacco products of $167 per kilogram. This has been replaced by a choice of three options. Firstly, there is a hybrid option involving an ad valorem surcharge of 50.32 per cent of the final wholesale list price, which includes both the total weight based duty and the ad valorem component along with a weight based duty surcharge of $2.65 per kilogram. Secondly, there is a solely weight based duty surcharge of $147.90 per kilogram where there are no more than 1,200 cigarettes per kilogram. Thirdly, there is a solely weight based duty surcharge of $265.73 per kilogram where there are no more than 1,200 cigarettes per kilogram
I commend the bill to the House.
