SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill 1997 seeks to implement a number of changes to the defence service homes scheme that were announced by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) on 3 September. The main aspect is to introduce from 5 January 1998 a guaranteed minimum interest subsidy of 1½ per cent compared to the benchmark market rate.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition does not oppose the bill, which will benefit some 52,000 veterans. We view the government's measures, however, as clearly being a case of too little too late. I have to say it is not Robinson Crusoe in regards to activities in this portfolio. As we have witnessed over the last year, we have had months of delay regarding disability pension changes. They were very welcome, but there were months of delay because the minister could not get that piece of legislation any priority in the House.

There are some people who are unsure as to whether it will eventually pass. They do not make claims and therefore cannot backdate further than three months. Similarly, in regard to vocational training—initiated by the previous Labor government—the situation was again that the minister, due to his inability, his lack of clout in the government, allowed this particular measure to be attached to measures in regard to eating up the rollover superannuation of people over 55. Once again it had to be delayed because the opposition and the Democrats could not agree to that attack on older Australians.

Similarly, we have a situation where the minister has allowed the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel (Mrs Bishop) to stuff around—with four attempts, at the moment—in regard to finally getting medals right and trying to argue today that some people's future in regard to medals—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: the member is taking a very wide berth around the topic of discussion, which is defence service home loans. It does not range into medals; it does not range into employment, education and training. I would ask that you direct him to bring his debate back in line with the topic of discussion.

—As I understand it, this is a fairly wide ranging debate. Whether it be training or medals, it is all defence related. Although the honourable member for Reid may be drawing a fairly long bow, I know that he is addressing his comments to the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill. His comments have all been defence related.
—As indicated, there is a variety of areas where—as with this bill—the government's measures, whilst commendable, have been too little too late.

SPEECH.PARA: The provision of housing loans to veterans with war service has a long history in the Australian repatriation system, dating back to 1919 in the immediate aftermath of World War I. The concept of war service loans is one that enjoys ready understanding and strong support in the community.

The details of the scheme are now somewhat complex. Eligibility is generally based on the veteran having operational service overseas. Between December 1972 and May 1985, the scheme was also used as the mechanism to provide home purchase assistance to regular personnel serving in the ADF. Whilst many retain eligibility from this period, people joining the ADF after 14 May 1985 are eligible for assistance under the defence home owner scheme, which commenced operation in January 1991.

Loans under the scheme are on a fixed rate basis, and borrowers in similar circumstances can be paying different rates of interest on their loan, depending on when they took out their loan. As well, loans taken out between December 1974 and December 1988 generally contained two or three so‐called tiers, with a different interest rate applying to each tier. Separate arrangements, and a higher rate of interest, have also applied to additional loan advances or advances for essential repairs to the home.

For many years the scheme was administered by the Defence Services Homes Corporation, a Commonwealth statutory authority. In October 1988 the Hawke government announced that it had sold the existing defence service homes portfolio and the right to provide future war service loans to Westpac, for some $1.4 billion. The corporation was then wound up.

Under the arrangements that have applied since that sale, the Department of Veterans' Affairs issues certificates of entitlement to veterans qualified to receive subsidised loans. The department then pays an interest rate subsidy to Westpac, based on the difference between the DSH loan rate paid by borrowers and the benchmark market rate of mortgage rates charged by the five biggest banks. This subsidy arrangement is the key to this bill, and I will return to it shortly.

For the vast majority of DSH borrowers the effective interest rate on their loan is 6.85 per cent, even if the actual loan contains several tiers. This rate has been in force since October 1980, some 17 years. Over the intervening period, there have been many changes in both the cost of housing and home loan interest rates. The fixed rate nature of the scheme has provided veterans with a secure arrangement that protected them from fluctuations and the boom and bust cycle that has impacted on the general community. At the same time, however, it has also restricted the ability of the scheme to adapt to changing needs and circumstances.

Reserve Bank data shows that in October 1980, when the 6.85 per cent DSH rate came into effect, market mortgage rates for owner occupied housing stood at 10.5 per cent. This meant that borrowers taking out a loan at that time were, effectively, obtaining an interest rate subsidy from the government of 3.65 percentage points.

In the intervening period, however, such mortgage rates have varied from 17 per cent to 6.7 per cent, implying an interest rate subsidy to DSH borrowers of between 10.15 per cent and minus 0.15 percentage points. During the 13 years of the Labor government, the effective interest rate subsidy on a 6.85 per cent DSH loan never fell below 1.9 per cent. Under the coalition, since August this year the main DSH rate has actually been higher than the variable mortgage rate charged by the private banks.

I acknowledge that the above comparison is based on a different market benchmark than that contained in DVA's agreement with Westpac. My figures are based on official Reserve Bank monthly data on the bank's new variable rate housing loans for owner occupation, which has been consistently applied for the 17‐year period examined by the opposition. Similar times series data on movements in the benchmark rate applied under the DVA‐Westpac agreement are not available to us.

Whilst borrowers are most unlikely to be unhappy about recent falls in interest rates, veterans with a DSH loan have good reason to be dissatisfied with the government's performance. On the one hand, we have seen the Treasurer (Mr Costello) rightly demanding that the private banks pass onto their customers, in full and without delay, welcome falls in official interest rates. On the other hand, for months the same government pretended that these falls had no implications for its own war service loans scheme.

A cursory examination of the budget papers reveals the explanation for the coalition's inaction. At the time of the 1996‐97 budget—the coalition's first—the interest rate subsidy payable to Westpac for the scheme was estimated to be $49.7 million. In fact, the actual subsidy paid to Westpac that year was only $30.2 million and the estimate for this financial year a mere $22.1 million. These figures clearly show that, over the past year, the coalition has been pocketing the savings on the interest rate subsidy to Westpac, rather than passing these savings on to borrowers, who are the veterans it is supposed to be helping into home ownership.

These figures provide the context for an honest examination of the government's package of measures contained in the bill. What we see is veterans having to wait until next January to receive what is, in effect, a cut in interest rates of a mere 1.22 percentage points—from 6.85 per cent to 5.63 per cent, based on the DSH benchmark rate currently being 7.13 per cent. As I say, they have to wait until January in a situation where there have been marked interest rate reductions over a very significant period of time and the concessional nature of the loans has been severely undermined.

Interestingly, I note that the Treasurer gave other borrowers firm advice on how to assess the appropriateness of the interest rates they were paying. According to an AAP report of 30 July 1997, he said:
I say to the small business proprietors of Australia, you should today be paying two and a half per cent less for your business loans than you were a year ago.

The opposition's main concerns are thus both the delay in passing on any cut in DSH rates and the actual amount of the reduction. As I mentioned earlier, at no time under the previous government did the effective interest rate subsidy fall below 1.9 percentage points, whereas the coalition is providing a `guaranteed' subsidy of 1.5 percentage points, starting next January.

I stress that the opposition has no objection to the overall design of the measures contained in the bill. The concept of providing a guaranteed subsidy that will apply within a certain interest rate band is a sound one, as this overcomes in‐built obstacles to making frequent amendments to the legislation.

I also welcome the fact that the bill effectively converts tiered loans into a single rate or so‐called blended loan, with the interest rate being either 3.75 per cent, 4.5 per cent or 6.85 per cent—the latter, of course, will be further reduced under the guaranteed subsidy arrangement. I know from callers to my office that many veterans with two or three tiers to their home loans found it hard to understand the effective total rate applying to them. Many with 10 per cent tiers also expressed frustration that they could not pay out a single tier of the loan, when they saw private lenders offering loans at a much lower rate. These people will be the particular beneficiaries of the bill. Having one single interest rate per loan and no‐one paying more than 6.85 per cent—further reduced by the guaranteed subsidy—are worthwhile measures, which I am happy to acknowledge.

Ex‐service organisations have approached me as shadow minister about other concerns they have about the defence service home loan scheme. It is notable that the groups representing Vietnam veterans have shown particular interest in the scheme, as their membership is more likely to be contemplating a home purchase.

The most frequent concern is, of course, the fact that the $25,000 maximum limit for a loan has not been increased since 1980. Over the intervening time, there have been astronomical increases in housing prices, particularly in major cities like Sydney. In that housing market, $25,000 is more like a deposit than a realistic housing loan. Veterans also hide the fact that the maximum loan available to serving ADF personnel under the defence home owner scheme is now $80,000. Whilst I acknowledge that the design of the two schemes is radically different, there is clearly a degree of inequity in the treatment given to those with war service. I would seek an assurance from the minister that the government will review the $25,000 upper limit in the near future.

To be able to purchase a proper home, veterans are effectively required to take out both a subsidised DSH loan and an unsubsidised market mortgage. In this regard, Vietnam veterans have expressed concern at the fact that the DSH rules insist on holding the first mortgage. This appears to have the effect of locking veterans out of the growing and generally cheaper non‐banking loan sector. This sector generally restricts its lending to first mortgages, putting veterans with a DSH loan at a particular disadvantage. It has even been suggested to me that some veterans are actually financially better off, in the short term at least, taking out a full mortgage on a low interest rate with one of the non‐bank lenders than taking up the $25,000 DSH loan topped up with a second mortgage from Westpac or another bank. I would be interested to hear the minister's response to this aspect.

Finally, I would like to express concern that new DSH borrowers, while likely to be these younger veterans, as those with Vietnam service, are to be hit with a $4 per month account maintenance fee from Westpac. This fee is not included in this bill, presumably because it is to be imposed administratively by Westpac. Whilst the minister claims that this fee represents a 50 per cent discount on the fee that Westpac imposes on other borrowers, it is disappointing that the government has not taken a stronger approach in negotiations with Westpac. As a result, new borrowers will lose $48 a year from the benefits provided by this bill. I reiterate that the opposition does not oppose the bill and will not delay its passage through parliament. We remain disappointed, however, with the timing and amount of the rate cuts announced by the government and seek action on other outstanding concerns about the scheme. I look forward to hearing the minister's response to our concerns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure I rise to speak to the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill 1997 . When the Anzacs came back after the First World War they were beginning to find that war never leaves a nation where it finds it. When the hurly‐burly is done, it matters little who lost or won. The participating nations had merely a file of marching prisoners chained together by treaty obligations and stiff‐necked pride and stupidity. Its causes, as US President Woodrow Wilson said in 1917, were lost in antiquity. Glory had decayed long ago in the trenches and now there was realisation that the land that they had been promised would be made fit for heroes would become worse than they had known it and the working man, as before, would carry his pick and shovel until he died—if he was lucky enough to be given work.

SPEECH.PARA: The returned soldiers banded together in nostalgia and silly talk, like `eggs‐a‐cook', jokesy terms, `whiz‐bangs', `shell holes', `duckboards', `gyppos' and `furphies'. Reunions were organised and many would retreat further and further into their associations for returned men. At that time in Australia's history, most women believed it was better to be a soldier's widow than a coward's wife.
The men asked for work—any work. In their news sheet, the 22nd Battalion presented a poem, and I would like to quote it:
And if you want a slushy or a station overseer,
And a tinker or a tailor or a snob;
Or a `andy bloke wiv `orses or a mining engineer,
We've got the very man to do yer job.
Butcher, baker, undertaker, and a Caf de Pary chef,
'E is waiting keen and ready in the little AIF.
An' later when we land back in a mob
Per'aps we might be astin' for a job—
So, we ask, what about it?

The returned men soon learned that they were only considered when needed as fighters. They had no say in peace. As for their return to civilian life, the passage of the discharged soldier settlement acts in all states during 1916‐17 began, according to economist Brian Fitzgerald, one of the most expensive and least profitable public ventures in Australia's history, the soldier settlements. The Commonwealth had guaranteed to meet the cost of settlement but it was a debacle only equalled by the effect on the men who had tried to make a living from the acres. Most lost their properties, unable to keep up the payments.

No money was going to stock them or to put a proper house or fences or anything on them. Properties were given away for the cost of a ticket south. It was a rotten scheme. No man today farms those desolate acres that had been sold as land fit for heroes. Within a few years, for every returned man carrying rails on the line, there were five trying to get a job. It was the atmosphere in which the war services homes scheme was established in 1918. It was obvious that an affordable scheme for housing to the returned soldiers was required to cope with the pressure of ex‐soldiers who could not afford to keep up with the full interest rates.

In 1972, just after the Vietnam War, its name was changed to the defence service homes scheme to recognise the extension of eligibility to those with qualifying peacetime service. The defence service housing scheme provides financial benefits in recognition of the contribution of certain men and women who have served in the Australian Defence Force in either peace or wartime. The benefits include housing loan subsidies and other housing related benefits such as comprehensive home owners insurance cover at competitive rates.

Defence service housing borrowers who are suffering serious financial hardships also have access to a range of additional benefits, including assistance with essential repairs and a reduction in instalments. In 1985 the government decided to sell the defence service housing mortgage portfolio to the Westpac Banking Corporation, who then became the scheme's lender, in December 1988. The Commonwealth's responsibility under the defence service housing act for the administration of the defence service housing subsidy scheme and the defence service housing insurance scheme rests with the secretary to the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

The maximum home loan is $25,000, with the borrower currently paying the government's subsidised interest rate of 6.85 per cent. I would suggest to members and to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) that perhaps that amount needs to be revisited given the cost of housing today. The amount of subsidy the government pays is calculated on monthly, and based on the average of, standard variable home loan interest rates offered by the five major banks, which is currently at 7.13 per cent per annum.

The impact of falling interest rates has meant that defence service housing borrowers are no longer deriving any significant discount from the loan arrangements. In 1974, the rates were fixed at 7.25 per cent, and in 1980 at 10 per cent. At the time, these rates were concessional to or comparative with the market rates. To the many soldiers returned after war, including Korea and Vietnam, the scheme was God sent. To many it meant the very first real opportunity to buy a home.

To many retiring regular soldiers it was a bonus which was jealously guarded because it could only be taken once, and the time had to be right. Although the amount then was $20,000, which fell well short of the total money required to buy a home, the fact that the interest rates were well below the market rates meant that the total mortgage became affordable. Naturally this government has been very pleased with the reduction in interest rates. In fact, the interest rates are now lower than when man first walked on the moon, or, in military history terms, before the end of the Vietnam War, which is continuing good news for the economy in general.

The low interest rate level is tantamount to a sensible, forward thinking approach to get the economic fundamentals in this nation on the straight and narrow. Their low level has made home ownership more affordable for young families, couples and single Australians than literally for decades. However, the reduction in market rates for housing loans has also significantly reduced the value of the beneficial interest rates that have traditionally been available to borrowers under defence service housing schemes. Therefore, to ensure the scheme continues to provide genuine compensation for veterans, the government has introduced a guaranteed minimum subsidy of 1.5 percentage points, below the average standard variable home loan. With the current benchmark of 7.13 per cent, the interest rate on defence service housing loans will reduce to 5.63 per cent. In addition, the 10 per cent per annum rate for additional advances and advances for essential repairs, fixed in 1980, will be reduced to 6.85 per cent per annum.

Another important part of this bill introduces a single rate of interest for those borrowers whose loans may comprise two, or even three, different rates linked to a different level of borrowing. The effect of the new single interest rate date will depend on the current mix of interest rates on a particular loan, and it will benefit many borrowers.

I have in my electorate of Paterson many defence and ex‐defence personnel from both the Singleton army base and the Williamtown RAAF base who have settled there following postings at Williamtown air base and Singleton army base. For some time now, they have quietly but persistently sought my assistance to make representations to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to look into the anomaly of being able to get cheaper loans on the commercial markets.

This government has given priority to this bill, which will introduce substantially lower interest rates on veterans home loans provided under defence service housing. These reforms would come into effect from 5 January 1998 and benefit more than 52,000 borrowers.

Today, we have heard the member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson), the shadow minister for veterans' affairs, complain about the delays in times, but I would seek to remind the House that the previous government had 13 years to quite simply bring this package in, and to assemble a series of interest rates that were a set percentage below the current market value with a set ceiling. But they failed to do that. They failed to respect what the veteran community wanted, and today again we heard from the shadow minister for veterans' affairs that the home loan rate—the value of it, the $25,000—should be revisited. I suppose, in true Labor tradition, they were going to do that. What? In the 14th, 15th, 16th, 17th, 18th, 19th or 20th year they were going to do it? The reality is that they never did. They never listened and they never considered the option.

This Saturday, I am very honoured to have been asked to officially open the Vietnam veterans photographic and memorabilia display in Maitland. I can think of no better epitaph than to produce evidence that the government is committed to the men and women who have served in the defence of Australia and to whom we, as a nation, owe a significant debt—a debt that some, unfortunately, take for granted in society today but a debt that can never be truly repaid.

I am reassured in the statement by the shadow minister for veterans' affairs that this bill is welcome and supported. I am sure that all would wish me well in assuring the many veterans in our electorates that we, as politicians, do remember. I commend this bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vale, Danna, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill 1997 addresses a negative impact from the welcome reduction in market interest rates currently operating in the Australian economy as against the interest rates payable by borrowers under the defence service homes scheme. This legislation has been eagerly awaited by our veteran community and will set in place concessional interest rates for defence borrowers at 1.5 per cent below the bank benchmark rate.

SPEECH.PARA: This government fully acknowledges the fine service by the men and women of the Australian defence forces and in many ways and means puts the national gratitude into appropriate and practical effect. One important measure of such acknowledgment has been the defence service homes scheme which provides financial benefits to those servicemen and women who have served our country in war and in peace. These financial benefits include house related benefits such as comprehensive home owners insurance cover at competitive rates and provides defence service home borrowers who suffer serious financial hardship access to a range of additional support covering essential home repairs or reduction in home repayments. One of the most significant financial provisions is the subject of this legislation, being the retention of an interest rate advantage, now to be maintained at 1.5 per cent lower than the bank benchmark rate.

The history of the defence service homes scheme goes back to 1918 when it was established as the war service homes scheme. The name of the scheme was changed in 1972 to the defence home service scheme to provide for the inclusion into the scheme of those who also served our nation in peacetime. In 1985 the government sold the defence service homes mortgage portfolio to the Westpac Banking Corporation, which became the scheme's lender in December 1988. Currently, the maximum loan under the scheme is $25,000, repayable over a 25‐year period. Under the agreement between the Commonwealth and Westpac, the Commonwealth subsidises Westpac for the low interest loans provided.

There are around 90,000 defence borrowers who will benefit under this legislation. Loans are available to buy, build, enlarge, complete, modify or repair a house or unit or to refinance a mortgage over a house or unit. Loans are also available to allow defence borrowers to buy into certain retirement properties or to obtain granny flat accommodation on another's property. The government is mindful of the impact of residential needs on the general health, comfort and wellbeing of our veterans, most especially our elderly veterans and their ability to continue to live in the dignity and independence they deserve. In such circumstances, situations of safety and security of their homes and the suitability of housing to meet special needs are of concern to this government.

By its initiatives in the 1995-96 budget, the government has implemented various policy measures which significantly improve the flexibility of and access to defence service home benefits. These include extension of eligibility to full-time members of the World War II women's services, assistance where the property title is to be held in tenants‐in‐common, assistance where the property title is a company title or leasehold holding and extension of access to defence service homes insurance for all eligible for assistance under the act. It also includes the stabilisation of terms and interest rates for further advances.

In the past, interest rates have been fixed by legislation. In 1974 the rate was 7.25 per cent and in 1980 the rate was fixed at 10 per cent. During these times the interest rate was concessional to the current market rates and reflected the objectives of the legislation to recognise the special status and standing of its defence recipients.

While the government is to be congratulated on the reduction of interest rates within the national economy, an unintended consequence of the government's sound economic management has been the significant reduction of the concessional interest rates applicable under the defence service homes scheme. This bill corrects this reduction and introduces a guaranteed minimum interest rate which will remain at least 1.5 per cent below the benchmark rate, irrespective of any future fluctuations in interest rates.

This bill provides the mechanism for a single rate of interest for those who may have two or even three loans at various rates linked to the different levels of borrowings. These measures will also provide for the abolition of the 7.25 per cent and the 10 per cent interest rates which have deprived defence borrowers of the well-deserved concession that they have every right to expect. The minimum interest rate subsidy of 1.5 per cent will be achieved by allowing the interest rate of 6.85 per cent flexibility to move down when interest rates fall or to be capped at that level if interest rates rise in the future.

As we have already pointed out, this legislation has much to do with the positive recognition of the fine service that has been proudly rendered to this nation by the men and women of our defence services and as such it will be genuinely well received across the country. There are, however, some defence personnel who have faithfully served our nation but who, for one reason or another, have not been sufficiently recognised for their loyalty and their service.

I refer to some veterans amongst my constituents, especially Mr Mervyn John Whitehouse, registration No. 50334, who lives in the bushland suburb of Waterfall in my electorate of Hughes and who served in the Australian Navy as a stoker mechanic on HMAS Anzac. Mr Whitehouse and his shipmates aboard HMAS Anzac were assigned with HMAS Tobruk to the Far East Strategic Reserve from 1955 to 1960. This was the Malayan conflict, in which our ships were deployed in support of the British fleet against the Communist insurgents in the Malay Peninsula. Both vessels initiated land bombardments upon the peninsula and the Johore area. Mr Whitehouse informs me that these two fighting ships have been recognised and are acknowledged on the honour role in the war museum at Kuala Lumpur.

This government has taken steps to recognise the valued contribution by Mr Whitehouse and his shipmates, and has recently passed legislation extending operational service benefits to all naval members of the Far East Strategic Reserve. This government has also granted the Australian Service Medal with clasp F.E.S.R. in recognition of such service.

Another of my veteran constituents is Mr Gordon Blake, who comes from the leafy suburb of Oyster Bay on the Georges River, which provides the northern boundary of the Hughes electorate. Mr Gordon Blake served on HMAS Melbourne in the gazetted operational area of a later conflict, the Vietnam War, in 1970. This ship was deployed in surveillance and support duties. To date, for one reason or another, Mr Blake and his shipmates have been denied recognition, although I can inform him that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) is currently investigating Defence records on his behalf.

Mr John Guy and Mr Ken Johnson, veterans from Engadine, served with the 133rd Heavy Anti‐Aircraft Battery defending Fenton, an airstrip in the Northern Territory, during World War II. This battery was credited with bringing down five enemy aircraft and fired more rounds than any other 3.7‐inch mobile heavy anti‐aircraft battery in the south‐west Pacific area during 1943. However, these veterans and their mates in the 133rd Heavy Anti‐Aircraft Battery have never received formal recognition for their service at that time and place.

Fenton airfield was a heavy bomber base for B17s of 64 Squadron, 43 Bombardment Group, United States Air Force, in August 1942. In January 1943 they were joined by B24 Liberators of the 90 Bombardment Group, followed in May by 528 and 530 squadrons. The airfield was visited on 13 December 1943 by the United States Army Chief of Staff, General George C. Marshall, who described Fenton as the loneliest base he had seen in a long while. According to Mr John Guy, he was not wrong.
In his letter to me, Mr Guy recounted some of his experiences. He said:

Sleeping under a mosquito net was a must for survival. The Japs kindly made us some large swimming pools with exploding bombs. When filled with water they made more work for us, having to be sprayed by knapsack sprays to keep the mossies from breeding. One had to be careful not to tread on the brown snakes which seemed to like the area. During the wet season, bed rolls had to be shaken to remove the scorpions which like to be dry.

Aussie ingenuity came to the fore during this time when supply trucks could not reach our gun sites without becoming bogged. Forty‐four gallon high‐octane petrol drums (empty of course) were split in halves, and dixies of food were placed in them and floated to our mess hut. No wonder so many of us suffered from chest related complaints when we were paddling around up to our fetlocks in water and rarely in dry clothes during the wet. Skin rashes and tropical ear were ever present hardships.

When the Japs couldn't destroy us with high explosive bombs they tried to burn us out by dropping incendiary bombs and setting fire to the American petrol dump. We fought for days to contain this fire with branches cut from trees. No luxury like water laid on in our camp at the Liberator heavy bomber airstrip, which we defended at Fenton.
This group, like the others, have failed to achieve recognition for their commitment and service because their period of active service does not appear to fit within certain guidelines.

I recognise that there are rules whereby recognition, either by way of medals or appropriate returned service pensions, is granted. But it seems to me that whenever and wherever Australian citizens proudly put on the uniform of our country, willingly take up the gun in our defence and purposely march or sail under the official orders of the Commonwealth, they formally make themselves a target on our behalf and it is proper and just that each should be acknowledged for their commitment. They intentionally cast their lot with the greater destiny which shapes all our ends and went willingly wherever our country sent them.

I acknowledge, and I am grateful, that our government is fully investigating the circumstances surrounding the service of these veterans. I also understand that in the hearts of such men of duty and discipline, recognition denied cuts deeply with an unrequited personal pain. I also personally acknowledge and respect their loyalty and service, and have today recorded their names and deeds in the great book of the nation for future generations to see. They are all fine sons of Australia; fine sailors and fine soldiers who were there for us when we needed them most. They are honoured as our veterans. Their history is our history, and it will always speak for them and accord them the respect and honour of the nation.

Having said that, and in contemplation of this legislation, I know that each and every one of them will, to a man, welcome and value this bill, and understand the recognition and financial benefits it will bring to their mates and fellow veterans, because that is the kind of true blue Aussies they really are.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill 1997 is of particular interest to people in the defence services in my electorate of Lindsay. We have the Glenbrook air headquarters establishment in my area, with 500 uniformed people. We have the 1CAMD establishment at Orchard Hills with several more defence people, and about 2,000 uniformed people out at Richmond air base, many of whom are living in my electorate of Lindsay.

BREAK.PARA: The defence home loans scheme was set up originally to make it easier for defence people to purchase their own homes, and this is important given the lifestyle that we ask of our defence people. They are subject to postings. There is some attempt to ensure that they are not posted too often, and we try to maintain them in situ for three years, but this does not always happen. In my six years with the RAAF I was posted four times. Every time I moved, there were expenses involved in that. Defence people are not always in an advantageous situation having to renegotiate loans, depending on the ups and downs of the market. So this scheme was introduced to give a service benefit for the lifestyle that we demand of our troops. For the services that they render it is almost a condition of service that they have access to cheaper home loan rates.

There have actually been several schemes to date, and they have been changed quite frequently, but today we are actually amending the interest rates paid on those schemes. I will look specifically at the $80,000 loan which most of those who joined in my era have taken advantage of—although there are still some constituents of mine who are on the old $40,000 Defence Force housing loan and the $25,000 Defence Force housing loan.

It does actually affect me, in particular, because I qualified for a Defence Force housing loan after my service. You are able to take it within two years of discharge from the military forces. At the time when I was discharged, I looked around to see how valuable that was, and when I looked at the interest rates at the time, it appeared that, in fact, it was yet another condition of service that had been whittled away over the previous few years. So it is imperative that we bring in this amendment to allow that condition of service to continue.

The interest rates were fixed in 1974 at 7.25 per cent and in 1980 at 10 per cent, and not much has happened since then. Currently, there are approximately 15,000 loans with an effective interest rate of more than 6.85 per cent. I have made a number of representations on this issue and I am glad to see that, as usual, our government is responding to the needs of people in my electorate. If you go to the National Bank at present you can get a current interest rate on a one‐year fixed loan of 5.49 per cent per annum. That is the interest that you would take your $80,000 out on for the first year, and it then transfers to the variable rate which is currently running at 6.7 per cent.
In addition to that, the Defence Force home loans will actually subsidise the repayments. So, if you have borrowed $80,000 under this scheme, repayments would be $577.43 a month—

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—Sorry. It would be $4,353 per year in the first year, so basically you would be paying monthly repayments—or fortnightly repayments, I think it is—at $577.43. Of that amount, the government subsidy which they will pay in addition to, or in place of, your repayments is $122, so the customer only pays $455 in repayments. That is certainly a substantial amount of money for those raising children and paying off a mortgage, in a situation where they are posted regularly and experience numerous additional expenses because of that.

BREAK.PARA: The scheme ensures that the interest rate that is fixed at 6.85 per cent is allowed to move down when interest rates fall; but, most importantly, it cannot rise above 6.85 per cent if interest rates rise. That certainly makes it a much more attractive scheme than is currently the case. These arrangements take effect from 5 January next year and, as such, I am still in time to take advantage of my loan, should I choose to do so, because it does expire. It has also recently been extended to reservists, which is an excellent situation for those who give up their spare time in our armed forces.

The actual defence service housing loan at this stage is also available through the National Bank, and some parts are also available through the Westpac bank. We do not look after our members with only those two banks; we have also established the Defence Force Credit Union, which has a facility on each of the three bases in my area and which offers exceptional home loan, personal loan and car loan rates, with limited penalties for early repayment and with no loan application fees or monthly administration fees, free loan protection insurance and also mortgage offset accounts.

It is still a very complex situation when people in the defence forces are thinking about buying a home, but it has been made financially a lot easier by the passage of this legislation. When they do buy a home, it has to be for their personal accommodation, and that is very important for people in defence. I know that a lot of couples in defence tended to think that they were only going to be in a situation for three years and, as such, would not really make the place home. So, for three years, they would live in temporary digs and not do an exceptional amount to really decorate their house and make it very personal. Then they would be posted, and on and on it would go.

Others, on the other hand, would establish a home very quickly and make it theirs, and would maintain a standard of living that civilians take for granted. So it has been a major incentive for people to actually start making homes as soon as they are posted and arrive in an area, to set up home and make the place theirs in a family support situation. In my experience in the RAAF, the couples and families that did that certainly were not coming to see me, as a lawyer, for family law matters quite as early as did those who had not tried to establish some sort of home and who lived the almost gipsy lifestyle of people in our military.

It is important to maintain that mobility of our forces, and that sense that they are not in a place for a permanent amount of time, because that is the nature of conflict and it is the nature of situations for which they have been trained. They will be fluid and they will be fast moving; and we do try at all times to ensure that they are going to feel comfortable and secure that their family, their loans, their funeral services, their wills and anything else that needs to worry them is taken care of, so that they can focus totally on the job that is at hand, which is the defence of Australia. It is perhaps a small condition of service, but it is an important one. I feel sorry that it is not entering earlier than 5 January, but at least it is being put in place, and the recognition and action are taking account of the very fluid home loan interest rates that are available.

At present there are three tiers of interest rates that are applied to defence service home loans. Those three tiers will be replaced by a single rate. At present the rates are: from $0 to $12,000 it is 3.75 per cent; from $12,001 to $15,000 it is 7.25 per cent; and from $15,001 to $25,000 it is 10 per cent. That system is being amalgamated and it is becoming a 6.85 per cent across-the-board loan rate. It is a beneficial measure; there will be no adverse effects.

The DSH rate certainly is more valuable when interest rates are high. Although it may be very attractive to seek loans from outside the scheme in low interest rate periods, it is certainly a scheme which affords a certain amount of protection when interest rates are high. And as we all know, what goes down, in a fiscal sense, will eventually come up. I certainly hope that is the case in light of yesterday's crash on our financial markets.

TALK.START.PARA: —New York has gone up today.

—I noticed that. The US markets did go up overnight and I am confident that by the close of business today we will see a significant recovery in our own situation. That will enable the low interest rates that Australians have been enjoying for the last 12 months under the stewardship of this government to be maintained throughout our time in government as we try to get away from that hurly‐burly of high inflation, high interest rates, boom and bust, that has so marked Australia over the last seven years.

BREAK.PARA: We have made exceptional progress in this area to date and we will be continuing along this path of making things easier for home buyers. That is essential for me because my electorate of Lindsay is a home buyers area. It is in the mortgage belt in western Sydney. We have a number of young families who are first home buyers in the beautiful Nepean valley, in the Penrith valley, and they are paying off mortgages. Certainly, the good news on interest rates has been of significant benefit to the people in my electorate, and for all the Defence Force people in my electorate it has been of great assistance to them as well.
I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis, Colin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My contribution to this debate will be brief. The Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill 1997 is intended to amend the interest rate on defence service home loans. It is a fixed rate, as has been said, that is about 1½ per cent below the benchmark.

SPEECH.PARA: As indicated by the shadow minister, the member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson), the opposition does not oppose this bill and we will not delay its passage. However, if we do have any disagreement with it then it is in the timing and the amount of the rate cut announced by the government.

The bill will benefit 52,000 veterans. No-one disputes the significant debt Australia owes to the men and women who have served in the defence of this country. This legislation will preserve and protect one of their longstanding compensatory benefits, a subsidised housing loan under the Defence Service Homes Act 1918.

As we are all aware, interest rates, in general, have fallen significantly in recent years and not, as those opposite would have us believe, since they gained the Treasury benches. I thought it was a bit rich of the honourable member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) to indicate that in the 18 months that the Liberal Party has had stewardship of the Treasury benches interest rates have dramatically fallen. I well remember that interest rates fell dramatically when Labor was in power. Indeed, it is because of the policies established under the Labor Party that interest rates have come down to the extent where so many people are now enjoying them.

I suppose there are no wins without pain and, as a result, the reduction in interest rates, especially in the market rates for new houses, has been significant. Of course that then made the benefit that was obtainable through these defence loans not such a benefit, as other speakers have said. This bill proposes a guaranteed minimum subsidy that will ensure that defence service home borrowers retain an interest rate advantage of at least 1.5 per cent lower than the benchmark rate, regardless of future changes in market interest rates. That is the important thing: it is regardless of future changes in interest rates. It is the changes in market interest rates that have eroded the benefit of this.

The measures in this legislation will come into effect on 5 January 1998. While speaking on the Defence Service Homes Amendment Bill 1997 , I will also take the opportunity to mention the Defence Housing Authority. Although it is important for defence personnel, and former defence personnel, to be able to purchase their own homes, it is also important that defence personnel posted throughout Australia are housed in decent accommodation. It was particularly interesting to hear the honourable member for Lindsay draw attention to the fact that in the six years that she was in the forces she had four moves. So often we hear of people with 20 years of service who have had 18 or 20 moves in that period.

When I first joined the Public Works Committee, and before the Defence Housing Authority was there, I recall being appalled at how many of our defence personnel were housed in appalling conditions. One of the great successes of the Australian Labor Party, when in government, was the establishment of the Defence Housing Authority. Since its establishment in 1988, it has housed 17,111 personnel; 10,294 houses have been purchased; and 6,817 house have been leased. The scheme has always had my enthusiastic support. Indeed, it is the envy of much of the world.

It is a realistic scheme based on market forces and it mixes defence and civilian personnel together in housing estates. The Defence Housing Authority has always had a very commercial approach and some of the estates, especially Willow Vale in the electorate of the honourable member for Hughes (Mrs Vale), are a real credit. Indeed, the housing estates in the Northern Territory have won awards for Troppo Architects. I am very proud, as a member of the Labor Party, that we did bring that in. The present government is of course keeping the DHA going, as indeed it should. I hope that the DHA and the defence service homes scheme can continue to enjoy the bipartisan support it has had over the years.

I would also support the comment by the shadow minister expressing concern that the $25,000 limit has not been increased over a number of years. There have been huge increases in housing prices, especially in Sydney and other cities throughout Australia. While serving ADF personnel can obtain a loan of $80,000, veterans are limited to loans of $25,000. I join with the shadow minister in seeking an assurance from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) and the government that they will review the $25,000 upper limit in the very near future. Indeed, I noticed that the honourable member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin) also made a plea for the $25,000 limit to be reviewed. But of course the honourable member for Paterson, in this very bipartisan debate, could not help having a go at the former government when he said, `What did they do in the 13 years that they were in power to ensure that that rate was lifted?'

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very good point.

—It might be a very good point, Minister. But I remember when at one time—and for whatever reason—housing interest rates were 17 and 18 per cent, my own brother was getting a loan at six per cent from the Defence Housing Authority. I was paying 18 per cent interest on mine. Over those years when housing interest rates were very high, those veterans did get a considerable advantage. It is only over recent years, when interest rates have fallen so dramatically, that that advantage has been eroded. That is why I congratulate the minister and the government in making it a fixed rate. Regardless of how interest rates fall, there will always be a compensatory advantage there. I think that was the original idea and is to be commended.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also some concern about the $4 per month account keeping fees imposed by Westpac. I know that Westpac say, `That is lower than the normal fee. The normal fee is $8 and we are doing it for $4.' Although it is not covered by the legislation, new borrowers will automatically lose an additional $48 a year from the benefits provided by this bill.

BREAK.PARA: It really is time that someone—whether this parliament or someone else—took on the banks. It is not only this $4 per month that they will charge; they will also charge a whole lot of other things. I know that every time I get my bank statement—and I have a loan, not at 18 per cent now, but I do have one—there is not only the bank keeping fee; there are all sorts of other things there too—$4 for this, $2 for that and the $8. The banks have for too long been ripping off the people of Australia, making those massive profits. Maybe it is time that someone took them on. Although the keeping fee is not part of the legislation, I think it is important to draw attention to that.

I am not sure about it—and I realise I should have alerted the minister to this before—but I take it that injured service personnel would still be eligible for this and repairs to the house and so forth that often the defence forces do. In my area I have the Injured Service Personnel Association. I know that when people in the defence forces get that compensation, quite a lot of work has to be done to their houses—doors, ramps and so forth.

It is very important that this legislation come before the House and be approved. I think it is to the credit of the government that they had realised this problem. We have indicated that they have been a long time bringing this legislation up. It is all very well for the member for Paterson to say, `The Labor Party did nothing for the 13 years that they were in power.' Nevertheless, if it was such a major item of importance to the government, one would have thought that they would have moved more speedily in the 18 months that they have been in power than they obviously have.

It is very important that our defence personnel and former defence personnel be housed in adequate housing. We do expect a lot of our defence personnel. We expect that, when they join the defence forces, they will make a commitment that they will move—often at very short notice—to many parts of Australia. They will be forced to move, to give up their home. As the honourable member for Lindsay said, often they have put a lot of attention into that home. It is very important that the government ensure that they are adequately housed and that, after they have left the services, if they so want it they can then get this loan. It is not all that much. That is why we are asking the minister if he could possibly lift it a little.
As indicated, the opposition does not oppose this legislation, but we do seek certain assurances from the minister and we look forward to his response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—Firstly I would like to thank my colleagues for their contributions to this bill and also, mostly, their positive and thoughtful comments—not always positive from the other side of the House. I thank both sides of the House for their contribution. I was a little bit disappointed in the opening comments by the member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson), the shadow minister, who sought not to address directly the bill before the Main Committee. I will touch on some of his comments during my summing up.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say at the outset that this bill is all about ensuring that veterans continue to receive a measure of compensation in the defence service home loan—DSHL—arrangements. The government, like previous governments, has made a firm commitment to look after the interests of our veterans in our community. These are men and women who have served in the defence of their country and they richly deserve the generosity of us all for their sacrifices. This bill has come about only because of the disciplined approach taken by this government in the economic management of our economy.

BREAK.PARA: The commitment to cut the budget deficit has led to the repeated fall in interest rates. In fact, interest rates now are so low that the beneficial nature of the defence service home loan is almost being matched by the commercial home loan rates. What this bill does is to ensure that veterans on a standard defence service home loan will receive in future a guaranteed 1½ percentage point interest rate reduction below the market rate on their defence service home loan, to ensure that a genuine element of compensation is maintained in the loan. As interest rates fall, so will the interest rate on veterans' defence service home loans in the future. These changes will commence on 5 January 1998.

I would like to point out also that we have abolished for good the 10 per cent and the 7½ per cent interest rates which are enshrined in the existing legislation. So all those people who were prevented from paying off the 10 per cent tier first will no longer have to worry about it. It is gone.

I know that has been the subject of concern of veterans in most constituencies around Australia: they have in the past been prevented from paying off those higher interest rate tiers faster or ahead of the other tiers within the loan structure. If the benchmark rate were to fall in future to 7.13 per cent, for example, then the interest rate on a defence service home loan of $25,000 would fall to 5.63 per cent. However, I cannot stress enough the fact that the maximum interest rate on a defence service home loan is forever capped at 6.85 per cent. That is another element of this bill that is not only a good measure but is a commitment from the government that we understand and we care for our veteran community.

I table a document which will help members understand the three tiers that existed in the past, how they will be structured in the future and where the compensation and subsidies will apply. I urge members to discuss that with their ex‐service organisations and people in their own constituencies.

I would like just to touch on some of the comments made by members of the opposition and to talk particularly about some of the comments made by the shadow minister. He said in his opening remarks that I as minister and we as a government cannot get legislation through the House.

I remind the opposition that this legislation has been accorded category T status by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). This is legislation that has been given urgency status. That is a demonstration that we not only care but are committed to getting the legislation through the House so that it can benefit our veterans.

The shadow minister also said that we have done very little for veterans. I will touch on some of the things that we have done. We have now got a simplified claims system. We have got increased support for veterans' advocates around Australia. We have made sure that there are no fees payable for entry to the Australian War Memorial. The average time for benefits claimed—to be handled by my department—has been reduced from 167 days to 77 days. If that is not benefiting the veterans of our nation, I do not know what does. We have reduced the time by almost 100 days.

Veterans living in regional and rural areas now have better access to information, health and safety services and increased entitlements to medical grade footwear. The long overdue recognition of the Korean veterans is being provided by the preparation of a nominal roll. Veterans receiving a disability pension through the Department of Veterans' Affairs and aged pensions through the Department of Social Security can now elect to receive one simple payment through my department—further streamlining of the operation and delivery of that income support to those veterans who have an entitlement from two departments. There is a range of other initiatives that the government has achieved in its first 18 months. I reject the shadow minister's comments that we have done nothing since we have been in government.

In relation to interest rates, I think the shadow minister was referring to the fact that he felt that this initiative could have been passed on sooner. All of us would have liked to pass it on sooner, but he would know that this has to be put in place by a legislative process and that it cannot be put in place until January of next year, as I have outlined earlier.

The shadow minister was critical that we did not increase the amount of the loan. I remind the Main Committee that the loans were last increased in 1980 under a coalition government. The opposition were there for 13 years and had an opportunity in 1988, when the defence service home loan was sold to Westpac bank, to put arrangements in place—if they really believed in what they were saying—to increase the loans, as part of the defence service home loan arrangements. It is gross hypocrisy for them to say in the Main Committee that they would like to see these levels raised, when they had an opportunity for 13 years to do so—and they had a very real opportunity in 1988.

In conclusion, the passage of this bill will provide immediate savings for entitled veterans. I thank all members of the Main Committee and the House who have contributed to this bill and also the opposition for their confirmation that they will not be preventing the passage of this bill. Like us, they want this bill to be put in place so that those beneficial measures can be passed on to the veteran community, starting on 5 January next year.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor‐General recommending appropriation announced.

TALK.START.PARA: —If no member wishes to consider the bill in detail, I will put the report question forthwith. The question is that this bill be reported to the House without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Review of Australian Honours and Awards

QUESTION.SPEAKER: West, Andrea, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 24 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Government (a) accepted or (b) rejected recommendations contained in the report of the review of Australian honours and awards; if so, what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has accepted thirty‐five recommendations in full and four in part; seven issues will remain the prerogative of Government House; and twenty‐one recommendations have not been accepted. The enclosed chart outlines these decisions. In addition, the Government has made four decisions on the Australian system of honours and awards unconnected with the report. These are shown on the chart

ROW.ENTRY: 1. That the Australian System of Honours and Awards be acknowledged as the pre‐eminent means of recognising significant contributions to Australia made by Australians and others.
2. The Order of Australia be retained as the pre‐eminent award structure within the Australian honours system.
3. Structural amendments which should be reflected in the Constitution of the Order of Australia:
. the structure of the Order to be three levels—Companion, Officer and Member;
. the General and Military Divisions to be merged so that there are no Divisions within the Order.
. eligibility criteria for the awards at each of the three levels to be redrafted to be clearer and more inclusive.
. a Group Award of the Order of Australia to be established and decided on the same basis as individual awards in the Order.
. a maximum number of 1000 awards to be available per year within the Order: no more than 1% at Companion level, no more than 10% at Officer level and no more than 89% at Member level;
. no change in arrangements for posthumous awards;
. honorary awards in the Order to be considered only for non‐Australian citizens whose home is not Australia.
Service in the Australian Defence Force
4. That a new Conspicuous Service Order be established to provide recognition for meritorious defence service. To have three levels: Companion, Officer and Member.
5. That the Champion Shots Medal be abolished.
6. That the Antarctic Medal be renamed the Australian Antarctic Medal with the postnominals AAM.
7. Endorse the continuation of the Australian Police Medal and the Australian Fire Service Medal.
8. That the Honours Secretariat investigate the feasibility of providing warrants to all recipients of meritorious service awards who did not receive them.

9. Endorse the continuation of the Public Service Medal. Recommend that the Medal be promoted more widely outside departmental public service structures and that announcements of awards should specify, where appropriate, the field of service or organisation in which the recipient has been employed.
10. That an Australian Ambulance Service Medal be created.
11. That an Australian Emergency Services Medal be created.

12. That the formula for award of the Australian Fire Service Medal, the Australian Ambulance Service Medal and the Australian Emergency Services Medal to volunteers be set at one award for each 5,000 members, or part thereof.
13. That feasibility of a community based merit award, outside the Order of Australia, be investigated further.
14. That the National Medal be withdrawn from the Australian honours system; and that employing organisations be encouraged to develop internal long service awards for their employees.

Not agreed. National Medal to be retained and expanded to include volunteer search, rescue and emergency organisations which meet the criteria. Medal Regulations to be rewritten to provide flexibility to accord appropriate recognition.
15. That a Voluntary Service Medal be established to recognise 15 years of service by volunteers in community service organisations.
Awards for non‐military service in specified activities

16. That eligibility for the Police Overseas Service Medal be extended to all Australian police personnel serving overseas in direct policing support of foreign governments or under the auspices of international peacekeeping or policing operations.
17. That a Humanitarian Overseas Service Medal be established to recognise participation in significant overseas humanitarian aid projects.
18. Support the proposal for retrospective awarding of the Antarctic Medallion to those Antarctic expeditioners who did not receive either the former British Polar Medal or the Antarctic Medallion.
Awards in the Sovereign's personal gift
19. That the Prime Minister ask the Sovereign to refrain from making further awards in her personal gift to Australians.

20. That the Guidelines for the Accepting and Wearing of Foreign Honours and Awards by Australians be modified to enable all Australian citizens, including Government employees, to accept the offer of a foreign award, subject to a Government veto where there is a foreign policy or national security reason to decline the offer.
Order of Precedence of Honours and Awards
21. That the Order of Precedence be replaced by a Guide to Australian Honours and Awards. And that the Department of Defence prepare its own Order of Wear for awards made to Defence Force personnel.
Community awareness of the honours system
22.That publicising and generating nominations for occupation specific awards be the responsibility of employing organisations and agencies.
Agreed, although Government will still wish to promote occupation specific awards as part of general promotion of the Australian honours system.
23. That a publicity strategy be developed to promote the Australian honours system.
24. That a public relations consultant be employed to advise on the development of an appropriate publicity strategy, including:

Agreed in principle. Publicity to be largely conducted using in‐house resources and expertise. Specifics of publicity strategy to be determined by IDC established in accordance with Recommendation 27.
information in translation as well as in plain English; and
appropriate and accessible alternatives to printed material.
25. That the Australian honours system be included in Civics curricula.
26. That the Department of Administrative Services take primary responsibility for promotion of the honours system.
Agreed. This function is now with the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.
27. That an interdepartmental committee be established to oversight the development and implementation of a publicity strategy.
28. That an information kit on the Order of Australia be developed
Agreed in principle. Specifics of publicity strategy to be determined by IDC.

29. Appointment of a public affairs officer within the Department of Administrative Services to develop the information kit and to establish and maintain community‐based information networks on the Order of Australia.
Not agreed. Publicity to be pursued using existing resources.
30. That the Department of Administrative Services promote the Order of Australia through regular advertising in national, ethnic and indigenous media.
Agreed in principle. Specifics of publicity strategy to be determined by IDC. This function is now with the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet

31. That citations for awards in the Order of Australia describe the service of the awardee more specifically, focusing on what the awardee has contributed rather than the field in which the service was rendered.
Agreed and implemented by the Secretary of the Order of Australia.
32. That information about the Australian Bravery Decorations be given a higher profile in publicity material on the honours system.
Agreed in principle. Specifics of publicity strategy to be determined by IDC.

33. Support and encourage the presenting of awards for bravery by community groups and employing organisations, but Commonwealth resources should be used exclusively to support and promote the Australian Bravery Decorations.
Agree to support and encourage presentation of awards but not agree that Commonwealth resources be used exclusively to promote Australian Bravery Decorations.
34. That a special publicity campaign be developed to encourage organisations to become accredited for the new Voluntary Service Medal.
Values as reflected in the honours system

35. That the nomination and assessment process for awards in the Order of Australia address the nominee's commitment to Australian community values as discussed in Chapters 4 and 6 of the RAHA Report.
Not agreed. Council for the Order of Australia to decide recommendations in accordance with criteria specified in the Constitution of the Order.
36. That inequities in award outcomes be addressed through raising awareness of award imbalances and through changes to award processes.
Agreed. Action taken to implement through publication of data in Government House Annual Report.
37. That businesses, government offices and community groups be encouraged to maximise opportunities to acknowledge award recipients.
Agreed in principle. Specifics of publicity strategy to be determined by IDC.
Administration of the Order of Australia
38. That a restructured Council for the Order of Australia continue to assess nominations and make recommendations to the Governor‐General.
Agree that Council should continue to make recommendations but restructuring not agreed.
39. Structure for the Council of the Order of Australia should include:
three ex officio members—the Chief of the Defence Force, the Secretary of the Department of Administrative Services, and the Vice‐President of the Federal Executive Council;
Agreed. A representative of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet will attend following abolition of the Department of Administrative Services.
one representative from each State/Territory; and
four nominees of the Prime Minister, one of whom should be able to represent the interests of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders.
Not agreed. Prime Minister will continue to nominate eight members of the Council.
40. That State/Territory representation be restructured; and that the advisory role of State/Territory governments be formalised. Recommended structure is:
each State/Territory be represented on the Council by one community representative;

each State/Territory community representative should be a person experienced in community consultation and accepted within the broader State/Territory community as an appropriate person to represent community interests;
each State/Territory representative would chair a State/Territory committee comprising community representatives and a representative of the State/Territory government.

State committees should be appointed by the Governor of each State on the advice of the State Parliament. The Northern Territory committee should be appointed by the Administrator of the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory committee by the Minister responsible for the Australian Capital Territory, both on the advice of the respective Territory Legislative Assemblies;

these committees would receive for written recommendation the names and addresses of persons resident in the relevant State/Territory for whom nominations have been submitted to the Honours Secretariat in Canberra, together with a copy of the full nomination form and all referee comments received. The advisory recommendations provided by the committees would be sent to the Council for consideration along with all other material obtained by the Honours Secretariat;
State/Territory committees should also promote community participation in the Order of Australia;
State/Territory representatives would be expected to comment on nominees from other States/Territories as well as their own;
appointment of State/Territory Council members and local committees to be for a term of 3 years with an option of a one term renewal;
a 50‐50 gender rule should apply with the details of appointment arrangements to be agreed at COAG.
41. With regard to the Prime Minister's appointees:
the number of Prime Minister's appointees be reduced to four;
there should be two males and two females at any given time;
each should be appointed for a period of three years with the option for a one term renewal;
each should be selected on the basis of his or her acknowledged standing in the community as a person of integrity and capacity to bring both local and national perspectives to the Council;
appointees should be representative of the diversity of the community and at least one appointee should be able to represent the interests of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders.
42. That the Chair of the Council be one of the Prime Minister's nominees who has served one term on the Council.
Not agreed. Governor‐General to appoint Chairman in consultation with the Prime Minister.
43. That a daily payment for reading papers and attending meetings be made to all those members of the Council not in government employ.
Agreed in principle. Subject to discussions between Council members, the Secretary of the Order and the Remuneration Tribunal.
44. That the nomination form for awards in the Order of Australia be revised in accordance with the draft in Appendix 23 of the RAHA Report.
Administrative details to remain prerogative of the Governor‐General and his Official Secretary.
45. The establishment of an informal network of local advisory centres to provide advice to prospective nominators for awards in the Order of Australia.
Agreed in principle. Specifics of publicity strategy to be determined by IDC.
Administration of the Australian Bravery Decorations
46. That the Australian Decorations Advisory Committee be expanded to include representatives of the Northern Territory and the ACT.
Agreed in principle. Subject to wishes of the Territories.
47. The introduction of a mechanism to enable speedy decision‐making and announcement of bravery awards.
Decision‐making processes to remain the prerogative of the Australian Decorations Advisory Committee in consultation with the Governor‐General and his Official Secretary.
48. That the Honours Secretariat provide research support to State/Territory representatives and Prime Ministerial nominees on the Council.
49. That every Council member receive access in full to all nominations and referees reports through the use of document scanning and CD ROM technology.
Administrative details to remain the prerogative of the Governor‐General and his Official Secretary.
50. That the Council meet more frequently.
Prerogative of the Council in consultation with the Governor‐General and the Secretary of the Order.

51. That the Honours Secretariat's function be reoriented to place a greater focus on servicing the community through monitoring of nominations and their sources and targeting under‐represented or unrepresented sectors of the community as nominees or nominators.
Not agreed. Nominations will be encouraged through a publicity program developed by the IDC responsible for honours promotion.
52. We recommend that the Honours Secretariat remain attached to Government House.
53. A major upgrade of the Honours Secretariat computer system to enable collection, analysis and public reporting on inputs to and outcomes of the system.
Administrative details to remain the prerogative of the Governor‐General and his Official Secretary.

54. That information on system inputs and outcomes be included in the Annual Report of the activities of the Office of the Official Secretary to the Governor‐General. And that the Registers of official awards maintained by the Honours Secretariat be available for public scrutiny.

Agreed in principle. However, details to be the prerogative of the Governor‐General and his Official Secretary, who will be guided by privacy and confidentiality considerations. Some details have been incorporated in the Government House Annual Report for 1995‐1996.
55. That all nominators be advised formally of the outcome of their nominations, after consideration by Council and the sounding of awardees has been completed.
Higher profile for the Council and its Chair
56. That at the time of announcement of awards, the Chair of the Council for the Order of Australia brief the media on that year's assessment process.
Prerogative of Council in consultation with the Governor‐General and the Secretary of the Order.
57. That the Honours Secretariat establish a data base to record details of referees and the frequency of their use.
Administrative details to remain the prerogative of the Governor‐General and his Official Secretary.
58. That, where referees disagree about the claims of a nominee, additional information be sought.
Agreed in principle. This is largely the current practice and remains the prerogative of the Council.
59. That additional resources be provided to enable the Honours Secretariat to implement proposed changes.
Not agreed. Costs to be absorbed.
Role of the Department of Administrative Services
60. That additional resources be provided to DAS to develop/implement a comprehensive publicity strategy.
Not agreed. Costs to be absorbed.
61. That the Government request the Sovereign to delegate her power to amend award regulations, including the Constitution of the Order of Australia, to the Governor‐General.
62. That all announcements in the Order of Australia be made once a year on Australia's national day.
63. That defence and defence‐related awards be announced on ANZAC Day.
64. That, as a general principle, awards which are occupation/activity specific should be announced on a day of significance for that occupation/activity.

Agreed in principle. Order of Australia awards will continue to be announced as outlined above, but police, fire, ambulance, emergency service and public service bodies may wish to consider announcing their meritorious service awards on days of particular relevance to their particular services, as is the practice with the Antarctic Medal.
65. That options for increasing community awareness of awards be investigated by the Department of Administrative Services.
Agreed. This function now with the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.

66. That the insignia for Companion, Officer and Member of the Order of Australia remain the same except that all should include a neck badge. And that the lapel badge currently used for Officer and Member be used for all levels.

67. With regard to insignia for proposed new awards, that a competition for new designs be held with particular emphasis on the inclusion of indigenous Australian colours and motifs. And that all new Australian awards include insignia which can be worn on everyday dress.
Agreed. The Government will approach selected designers rather than launch an "open" design competition.

BREAK.PARA: OTHER DECISIONS

ROW.ENTRY: Military Division of the Order of Australia

To be extended to allow retired members of the Australian Defence Force to be appointed to the Division or awarded the Medal of the Order of Australia in the Military Division so long as gazettal occurs within one year of retirement.

To be extended to allow appointment to the Division or award of the Medal of the Order of Australia in the Military Division to members of philanthropic organisations accredited to the Australian Defence Force.
Persons awarded Group Bravery Citations will receive insignia (at present they receive a certificate)
The three Defence Force Service Awards will be phased out and a single Defence Force long service award will be introduced.
